The lens is fast (meaning it lets in a lot of light) and the controls are excellent. The screen is also very good, being both sharp and vibrant. The file quality is as good as it gets for a small-chip (1/1.7") sensor. In this context, the camera is a solid 4-stars.However, I bought this as an upgrade from my Canon G9, purchased almost six years ago. While a few things are improved in the G15, there are a few critical things that are not and that is why I'm giving this camera a 3-star review.What's improved from the G9 (or many other P&S; cameras from that generation).-Screen is a lot better-Lens is 1 1/3 stops faster and appears sharper.-Camera body now has a decent grip with a rubberized leather-like texture.-Higher ISO shot ability (file quality is questionable)-Movie recording is now full 1080p HD-Auto-focus feels snappierThings that are about the same in practical terms, though I consider them negatives because they haven't improved over the years:-Same megapixel count (12mp or 4000x3000 pixel images)-Sensor is same size (1/1.7")-Same basic camera layout (neither good or bad thing)-Still requires many button pushes and deep menu access to achieve basic things even though the camera has 12 buttons (up from 11 on the G9). For example, it takes five button pushes to change flash exposure in any of the auto-exposure modes (P, Tv, Av).-While autofocus feels faster, taking a shot is actually still the same speed as the G9 - when going from idle state to the time when the shutter has taken a shot.-The tunnel vision viewfinder is really in need of improvement for a camera this expensive in 2013.-Camera over-exposes very easily and the highlights are not easy to recover even when shooting RAW.Things that are worse about the G15 vs older G-series cameras-The flash is now pop-up with a switch-The rear thumb dial is now combined with a 4-way button. So trying to rotate the thumbwheel to alter a setting can lead to accidental button pushes if one's touch is not light enough. In comparison, the G9 had a separate outer wheel and an inner 4-way button.In my experience the G15 is a modest update to a camera like the G9. I expected there to be more improvements in file quality, ergonomics, and resolution when compared to a camera that is six-years older. Overall, I'm disappointed in the G15 in the sense that it doesn't feel that strong of an update and I'll probably just stick to using my G9.

Reviews.Title: Most of the benefits of a DSLR for modest cost, amazing quality jpegs
Reviews.Author: Matthew Marlowe
Reviews.Content: Everyone has their own needs with regards to cameras, but many amateur photographers are encouraged to upgrade to expensive DSLR's in order to grow their skills and produce great shots.  DSLR's have their place, but the G15 - I think - provides all the features needed in a durable form so that, unless you absolutely are certain you need a particular feature specific to a DSLR, there is no need to upgrade.  The G15 on its own is wonderful: It shoots fast, has a great lens, and produces stunning jpegs.  There are hundreds of ways to customize and extend it.  And, it just makes taking pictures fun and a seamless experience.  The live view on the G15 is also super responsive.  You will find most of the features and issues specific to a DSLR are also applicable to the G15, although the lens on the g15 is not upgradeable like a DSLR would be.Also, if you give the camera to a novice family member to take shots, the auto mode is the most intelligent I've ever seen.....odds are they will still be able to produce great shots w/o knowing what they are doing.Caveats:- Zoom range is OK but not super, if you're doing a lot of outdoor landscape photography or shooting birds/etc....well, there are better cameras built specifically for that niche, like the canon SX50.- It will produce raw format files for those wanting to do extensive post production work, but when raw mode is enabled - there is a substantial slowdown.  I'm more of an action photographer, and the G15 can give me close to a sustained 2 shots/second for up to 45 minutes when in jpeg only mode.  After a certain point, the camera might start to overheat...and thats my clue to slow down.  DSLR's may have faster processors for shooting images in raw format....the G15 is optimized for jpeg all the way through.  RAW is just a slow add on for it.- The default aspect ratio on the G15 is 4/3 which is the standard for point and shoots.  However, 3/2 is a much better general use ratio that makes it easy to introduce still photos into HD video.  DSLR's make this easy.  For the G15, you have to switch to the 3/2 aspect ratio which immediately results in a reduction in about 1 Megapixel of image quality.- The camera is small which makes it absurdly easy to carry everywhere and to hold while capturing stills and video, but that size comes at the cost of both the articulating display in prior G series cameras and practical limitations on what size equipment you'll mount to it when doing professional work.  I can mount a speed 320ex speedlite flash to the G15 and it remains barely usable...I wouldn't mount a 430EXII.  A wireless transmitter would be fine though if you can mount flash's off camera.- You will get lots of anxiety from other photographers for using a camera with such a small sensor...however the sensor and image processor on the G15 is great quality and allows taking shots with lower than normal iso which is a big win.- You will see extensive image noise if you use ISO >= 1600, the G15 is extremely sensitive to ISO levels.  90% of your shots you will be able to take at ISO400 or below though, and you can minimize the need to increase ISO either by using flash or modifying shutter/aperture. You can also enable special modes that will significantly optimize the quality of highlights and shadows in your images at the expense of a slightly higher ISO.- If you are buying the G15 because it has an optical viewfinder, I'm not sure of the quality of it...I never use it, nor do I really miss the lack of the articulating electronic viewfinder.Just as update, the following are the accessories I recommend as the minimum to get the most out of a G15:- At least 1 additional Canon NB-10L battery.  I have three batteries total which is enough to get me through the most intense of shooting days.  The built in flash can deplete a battery in under an hour.  If you are not using flash, you can probably get 4000 or so still images or a few hours of video on a single charge.  However, the batteries take awhile to recharge...and I like to have at least 1 active and 1 spare whenever I leave the house...and all three batteries when on travel.- As mentioned above, the 320EX makes the perfect complement flash for the G15.  Even if you are happy with the built in flash quality of the G15, and the built in flash is more than OK, the 320EX provides the benefit of a much faster recharge interval which is most noticeable when taking night shots.  Taking sustained shots with the internal flash at night is an aggravating experience with a 5-6 second delay between photos, essentially removing it from being able to cover action events.  The 320EX minimizes camera slow down with a high burst capability and a fast ~2 second recharge when provided with nimh rechargeable AA's.- SLIK PRO 700DX Professional Tripod with Panhead (615-315), you will need a tripod to make the best use of the video, timelapse, macro, night, and built in HDR modes of the camera.  HDR especially is sensitive to any camera movement.- Optek Premium Reference White Balance Card - 3 Card Digital Color Correction Tool- SanDisk Extreme Pro 64 GB SDXC Class 10 UHS-1 Flash Memory Card 95MB/s SDSDXPA-064G-AFFP (I have three of these cards for multi-day travel that allow me to wait until I return from a 3-7 day trip before downloading photos).  Yes, the camera seems to have a snappier response and be able to sustain a higher continuous burst rate with the 95MB/s UHS-1 cards.  Those new to the G15 might scoff at the 64GB card size or the need to take 3-4K photos/day.....just wait until they have been shooting with the G15 for a few months..the camera is so quick to respond, especially in continuous mode for action shots...it is remarkably easy to find oneself taking 10x the photos one was taking with an earlier camera.  ~200GB is what I've budgeted as the maximum I need for a week or two of shooting.  I average ~8GB/hr.- Satechi MTR-C Timer Remote Control for Canon EOS 60D, Digital Rebel XT, XTi, XSi, XS, T1i, T2i, T3i & Canon Powershot G10, G11 & Pentax K7 & ELAN SLR (Camera)  -- cheapest and best way to take extended duration timelapse videos with the G15- Case Logic DCB-303 Vertical Flash Camcorder Case (Black) (Camera) - Smallest high quality case that comfortably fits the G15 and a few accessories.  I use this to house the G15 whenever I'm not using it, and I put this case into a larger leather one for extended travel.

Reviews.Title: The G15 is a precision instrument
Reviews.Author: David K.
Reviews.Content: I consider the Canon G15 to be one of the finest small cameras that I have ever used.  It outclasses other point and shoots in many respects.It is solidly built and handles like a precison instrument.  I am impressed by the full creative controls on the G15 and the ease of accessing them.  It of course has RAW and RAW plus JPEG capability; I would not have purchased it otherwise.  The camera fills the hand nicely.  It has a serviceable viewfinder, is of a discreet size, and has a rapid enough response for candid street or journalistic photography.  The image stabilization is very effective.  I am grateful for the exposure compensation dial, but wish that the ISO dial of earlier versions could somehow have been retained.  I am pleased with the ease of shutter and aperture adjustment in the creative modes.  The Auto Mode is excellent; however, it continues to share the vagaries of the auto white balance of other cameras.I would have rated it more highly except for what I see as two engineering tradeoffs, probably driven by marketing it as a "Powershot" (i.e. a point and shoot class camera).  Given today's technology, Canon's engineers should have been able to install a somewhat larger sensor, thus allowing the camera to take greater advantage of the magnificent f/1.8 lens; I would happily have paid the penalty of dropping to a 4x zoom.  Secondly, the utility of the camera is limited by the lack of a rotatable LCD; the additional minimal weight and bulk would have been worth it to me.Finally, there are two nit-pics which relate to getting the camera into action:  the flash hot shoe sometimes snags when withdrawing it from its pouch (no insert is available from Canon) and the power button is not sufficiently recessed to prevent turning the camera on accidentally.On the whole, the G 15 represents a set of clever and knowledgeable tradeoffs in re-engineering its icon small camera.  Considering of how Canon has met the challenges, I would rate it four-and-a-half stars.  I would expect a G 16 - if and when - to attain five stars.

Reviews.Title: Awesome and worth the wait
Reviews.Author: MunDog "MunDog"
Reviews.Content: I had been waiting for an update to G12 and Canon hit a bulls eye with this camera. One could argue about G1X etc but I was looking for not just something more portable and handy for the situations when I did not want to lug my DSLR equipment around but something which would provide me with all the creative possibilities and image quality at not breaking my bank price. The best feature on this camera is its lens and the new sensor. Pristine image with high quality and fast lens with usable wide to long range for everyday use. The smart pan feature is pretty cool. Auto focus is noticeably fast. The burst mode did surprise me for a camera of this kind. I have not explored auto mode as that is more of when my kids and wife needs to shoot but the manual controls with easy access buttons in the back are awesome. The body seem to feel like Magnesium. Not sure if it really is or if it is plastic. Small ergonomic preferences apart the camera is a winner. Great job Canon. G15 will rule in this segment.

Reviews.Title: Disappointing Product
Reviews.Author: B. Boyce "Photographer"
Reviews.Content: Quite a lot of research went into this purchase. For a number of years I have wanted a good quality small camera with 720p video capability to replace my 2005 Canon A710, which still takes great photos but no HD video.The Canon G15 has a solid build, took nice video without any focus seeking and was impressive in low light environments. Unfortunately the focusing accuracy shooting stills left much to be desired. Although the camera has an incredible close focusing distance, attempting to shoot a macro shot of a flower's stigma was impossible unless focus was set to manual. The G15 automatically focused on a leaf 3 inches further away. Good auto focus in macro mode is required when following insects on flowers or creeping up on a briefly paused dragonfly. My A710 does this beautifully.Most of the time the camera focused normally. Occasionally, however, subjects in the center of the frame would be soft while people or things a yard or so further would be tack sharp. (Zoomed in of course. Wide angle shots were fine.) Focus points were checked while reviewing results on my computer, using Aperture, to make sure it wasn't due to operator error. It is unacceptable to have good shots ruined by what should be a simple autofocusing situation.The color reproduction shooting jpeg was also disappointing. The Canon G15 suffered in comparison to the Canon SX40HS, SX260HS and even my 8 year old Canon A710. That great Canon saturation that many photographers love was missing. Possibly the problem is particular to this individual camera.Considering the Canon G series has a great reputation, most photographers will probably be satisfied with the Canon G15 camera. It's just not the camera for me.

Reviews.Title: Great Point and Shoot Camera with Manual Controls
Reviews.Author: Sententia
Reviews.Content: I got this camera as an upgrade from my Nikon Coolpix S8100. I originally wanted the G12 which has rave reviews but is currently selling for more than it's original RSP price with many vendors, but I was able get the newer G15 camera for a cheaper price in a bundle package around the holiday season.In terms of ergonomics, what I liked about my previous camera is that it seemed substantial without being too bulky and I wanted to continue that preference. But my main reason for upgrading is that while I thoroughly enjoyed my last camera, I realized I was hitting my limitations. I'm just now starting to get into photography because I want to take higher quality photos of my travels and many images that I want to take require some manual manipulation-something that my Coolpix couldn't do. However, I wasn't ready to jump up to a DSLR  or Mirrorless camera due to the investment involved. I thought this camera would be an excellent compromise due to the Powershot line being a favorite among photographers much more talented than I. Needless to say, it doesn't disappoint.I just came back from a trip to Malaysia and Singapore and I have so many great shots, particularly night shots with minimal noise w/o a tripod, something I had a hard time accomplishing with the Coolpix 8100, which was known for taking decent low light shots.  The ability to control the intensity of the flash is a great addition.A very durable camera as well that can take a beating, especially if you plan on backpacking through Southeast Asia as I was doing. Also, I like how easy and informative the interface is as you go through features which is beneficial for someone who hasn't had a camera with manual controls before. Although I've started out in auto and scene modes, I've rapidly moved over into other modes, particularly Program and Aperture Priority after only having this camera for a month. Eventually I'll progress to manual.  So the learning curve isn't that steep. Furthermore, I was surprised at how many fellow travelers I met with much nicer cameras ( some of them professional photographers themselves) commented favorably about my camera or asked to try it out.  I think that's a clear sign that Canon has built a solid line of cameras. Overall, I think this is a great discreet camera-particularly for travel.

Reviews.Title: Love it
Reviews.Author: Wayne Hodgkinson
Reviews.Content: Awesome camera.  As a user of a DSLR, I bought this for my wife, but find myself using it more than her now (oops).  With full control and great picture quality, what more do you need?

Reviews.Title: Perfect complement to my Canon t2i
Reviews.Author: V. CHAN
Reviews.Content: I am 62 years old and I have always had film or digital SLR cameras since I was in my 20's since I had considered point and shoot cameras to be inferior and not worth the photo lab or printing cost.  Currently I am happy with my Canon DSLR t2i except for the size and weight.  There are times when I am traveling light and I needed a compact camera but it has to provide near DSLR quality photos because I am spoiled with the great photos from my t2i.  My photos must be perfect because I tend to enlarge them to 36 by 24 and hang them in my living room for my visiting guests to admire. One of my guest thought that some of my photos were taken by a professional and not by my Canon t2i.While reading consumers report, the G15 was one of the recommended compact camera so I did my research on this camera and concluded that at $299 to $399, you can't go wrong.  After using it for a month, I was so happy with this purchase that I purchased a second G15 for my brother as a gift.Here are my favorite features:  (1)  programmable C1 and C2 settings on the top dial that instantly recalls my favorite settings without going thru the menu settings again.  (2)  If the flash is in the popup position, it will always flash and if the flash is retracted, it won't.  (3) The top exposure compensation dial to lighten or darken the photos which you can do very quickly.  (4)  flash output compensation to increase output to extend the reach of the flash or reduce the output to minimize flash washout of the subject.  (5) The three inch screen is stunning and even better than my Canon t2i.  (6) Generally, it has most of the controls of my Canon DSLR t2i but the G15 controls are more user-friendly and intuitive.  It seems like Steve Jobs must have designed this camera for a serious photographer like me who needed to set the camera settings as quickly as possible without fumbling thru the various menus.  (7)  The resulting photos are near DSLR quality which I thought was amazing given the compact size.While the photos are not quite DSLR quality and results are very close.  There are better cameras than the G15 but not one of them is a better value for the money that you will pay.  This camera is a perfect complement for people who already have a DSLR camera and needed a more compact camera with near DSLR quality.  For those buyers who don't want an DSLR camera, then this is the compact camera to get.  Five stars easily but I would give it 6 stars because I paid only half the price of my Canon t2i and this camera is so user-friendly. To appreciate the photos, you should transfer the photos to a 10 inch ipad with retina display.

Reviews.Title: Best Point & Shoot Available!
Reviews.Author: drumflight
Reviews.Content: My first digital camera was a G3 so I have some sentimental attachment here.... I have forgotten about my 5D, MkII and carry this everywhere I go. Love the simplicity, macro, high ISO and creative modes. Would have been nice to have a longer zoom but it still deserves 5 stars!

Reviews.Title: Canon PowerShot G15 is a winner!
Reviews.Author: MaryAnne T.
Reviews.Content: This camera is a winner. It's got an amazing lens, is easy to use, and compact enough to stow in your purse. I took it to Alaska and got some really beautiful shots. It worked well for action too like whales jumping out of the water and bears fishing in the streams. It has a great zoom for such a small camera, and does very high quality close-up shots as well. It does use a fair amount of battery but for all its features it's a classy little camera.

Reviews.Title: WILDLY PLEASED,,
Reviews.Author: Michael Movius
Reviews.Content: I as very pleased with this camera. Compared to my DSLR, it is extremely light weight, doesn't need a bunch of lenses or a carrying kit. Photo quality is the best. Don't bother buying the G16. The gimmicky features on that camera could never be worth an extra $100+.

Reviews.Title: Top Of The Line Compact
Reviews.Author: twill
Reviews.Content: This is Canon's current top of the line compact digital camera for non-professionals. Great product with all the features you will need without the bulk of DSLR rigs. Solidly built body metal construction that has some heft to it.I'm gearing up for a trip to Europe next spring and this is the still camera I chose to substitute for a Canon A1000. I also have a Canon Vixia M41 video camera. I am considering taking only the G-15 to Europe because the video quality is almost as good as the HD M41. In the end, I'll probably take both.I use an optical viewfinder most of the time. My only complaint is when the lens is fully extended about 10% of the lower left corner of the viewfinder is blocked. Since I seldom use the fully extended lens it's not a big deal.Battery life is very good.I guess the G-15 is what you would call a crossover. It's not a full featured professional rig but it's a lot, lot more camera than your typical point and shoot.

Reviews.Title: Love it...
Reviews.Author: Skeptical Buyer
Reviews.Content: I'm not even an amateur photographer, but I appreciate a picture that's better than something that I can take from my phone or from a traditional point an shoot.  There's a lot of great features which are included in most point and shoot cameras, but it also affords you the ability to make your own pre-programmable settings, or just override everything and operate everything manually.  The low-light settings that let you bypass a flash are some of my favorite features.  The crisp pictures really let you capture a scene/moment as you're actually experiencing it, as opposed to having a bright flash light highlight anything and everything within the scope of the lenses.  It's definitely larger than a traditional point and shoot camera, and is more suitable to a coat pocket than a pant pocket (very bulgy if it fits at all).  Although it doesn't have the range of functionality or capabilities of an SLR camera, it's highly functional and is significantly more compact and user friendly to the novice.  All around, a great camera.

Reviews.Title: Great camera!
Reviews.Author: Alfred Rohling "Gadget Guy"
Reviews.Content: This camera takes excellent pictures and videos. The pictures are sharp and clear and with an f1.8 lens, you have the flexibility to take low-light photos with no flash. Built-in ND filter allows for longer exposures in bright sunlight. I use mostly the Aperture mode, but there are many other options for creativity available. You have the option to shoot in RAW, jpeg or both. The optical viewfinder is very useful when shooting outside in sunlight. This is one of the main selling points of the camera.Far too many digital cameras that purport to be high-end models only have an LCD viewscreen available. If you can't frame what you are shooting, it makes it much harder to take a good quality shot.I also have several full-size DSLR's that I use, but in instances where I know I will walking a lot and don't need the extra zoom, I take the G15.Video quality is also excellent. I shot about an hour of video that edited down to a 10 minute video. Picture quality was almost indistinguishable from a dedicated video camcorder. The only time I noticed any difference is a shot where there is a lot of fast motion. In that case, there was some slight pixelation when I slowed down the video speed. But unless you are shooting fast-motion sports or racing, you won't see any degradation in video quality.I love this camera for it's flexibility. I don't have to carry a heavy DSLR and I don't both a camera and a camcorder on occasions when I shot photos and videos. Not the cheapest camera out there, but well worth the price. --- Also takes standard Canon speedlite flashes that fit on the Canon DSLR's.

Reviews.Title: Wonderful camera
Reviews.Author: Michael P. Wheat
Reviews.Content: I am an avid underwater photographer and spent two months going back and forth on this camera and the Sony RX 100.  I am SO glad I went with the G15.  Not only is the overall investment (housing and camera) nearly half of the other option but the results have been splendid!  The 1.8 lens is VERY bright and stays so as you zoom out.  Which is great for low light photography (i.e., underwater).  I have only taken a few macro shots, but have gotten excellent results every time.  This was the big difference to me between this camera and the Sony RX 100.  The Sony just can not take a macro shot to saves its life.  I spent half an hour in a store with both cameras trying to take macro shots of a quarter.  The Canon never struggled, while the Sony took attempt after attempt to finally get a decent shot.Happy to see Canon revive the G series!

Reviews.Title: Controls like a film camera
Reviews.Author: bitbob
Reviews.Content: The controls on the Camera remind me of my old film cameras. They put thing like =-3 stop exposure on the outside of the camera. Other standard film controls are there too and there is an optical finder that zooms with the lens. Feels good in my large hands and all the controls are very accessible to my grip. I like the lens range and Macro capabilities which are easy to use. The lens is good and sharp throughout its range. I will probably get a superzoom compact also just for the tele range but this on is a great pocket camera for all occasions with few compromises for an old film shooter.

Reviews.Title: Nice camera!
Reviews.Author: Mostly Harmless
Reviews.Content: I have had this camera for about two weeks now (including 300+ pictures during a one-week vacation).  I am very pleased with the G15 and recommend it.As others have noted, the camera's case is very precisely constructed and appears to be quite rugged.  The camera has a great feel in the hand, and part of this is due to the texture of the case (as well as thoughtful placement of controls).While this camera is too large for a shirt pocket, it is still considerably smaller than a SLR; it will easily fit into a jacket pocket and will fit into the front pockets of many pants (it is more or less the size of a man's wallet).  (The worst picture, by far, is the one you can't take because you don't have your camera with you!)Image quality is very good.  The 1.8 lens is fast and image capture is rapid (I will upload an image of a geyser - captured in one attempt).The optical viewfinder is very good for situations in which bright light is shining directly onto the digital screen.The battery life seems great - I captured around 300 images, with lots of reviewing by multiple people, on a single charge.I probably won't use all of the modes and settings possible on the G15, but still, they are nice to have (especially aperture priority).Recommended!

Reviews.Title: Great Little Camera
Reviews.Author: Drool
Reviews.Content: I bought one of these as a "between" camera so I have something better than a pocket camera camera without having to resort to my 20D or 5D MkIII.  I have found that even when I am lugging my full kit of 5D with lenses I have the little G15 around my neck too.  It takes great pictures.  No regrets for the swivel screen going away.  I wouldn't have used it and it increases the girth of the camera.  Battery life is excellent too.  Awesome low light performance for its sensor size.

Reviews.Title: Canon G15, Outstanding
Reviews.Author: Geoffrey Grant
Reviews.Content: This little camera produces high quality, sharp, color balanced photos. It can be run either manually or automatically depending on the wishes of the photographer. It's quality is well beyond the cheaper point-and-shoot cameras, but it is still light enough to carry easily.

Reviews.Title: Canon Powershot G15 Delivers!
Reviews.Author: LD Likes
Reviews.Content: I've had the G7 the G10 and now the G15. As a professional photographer I don't like to carry my expensive pro gear around when I'm out and about. Yet I want to have a camera on me at all times for personal shots, practice shots, and just having fun with my camera!The G7 was great. I bought the camera and canon case where I could loop the case to my belt and I had the camera with me at all times. It lasted about 3 years before the zoom lever spring broke. Fortunately I had bought an extended warranty and got the g10 as a free replacement. Good deal! The g10 came able to shoot RAW files and I used it quite a lot as I like to do some HDR photography and you need RAW files and a tripod for this. The biggest advantage though that I found of both these cameras is their Macro feature (able to shoot close up--just inches away from the subject). With the small sensor they give a lot of depth of field (more area in focus than even a pro macro lense!). I can copy text, or small objects, car parts, whatever with great clarity.The one downside to the G10 which was a 15 megapixel camera is that it had a lot of noise at 1600 ISO. I needed less noise when shooting indoors without using flash (shooting natural light). To offset the noise/grain in the image I used a software program to reduce it but typically the image would then look softer!Amazon allowed me to trade the G10 (which was still in good working order) and get approx. $100 off the price of a new G15. The G15 comes with a faster lense and has less noise at the higher ISO's and is slightly smaller in size. This is just what I wanted! It shoots great portraits in low light without flash.The G15 comes with a new pop-up flash and I cannot get any red eye when using it (which is just amazing!). I like that they have included a dedicated button for video and also I can now shoot HD video! They added a new dial for adjusting fstop and shutter speed which is great too! (before you had to jump through the menu's which was a pain).Lastly this camera and their new line of Canon Powershots now come with Smart Auto. Will go through 37 different program modes automatically picking the one that is best for your photography situation. If the subject is moving it knows to track it! If shooting close up it automatically goes into Macro mode! Etc...Etc.  About the only time I found it not useful is when the subject is back lite! I had to pop the flash and manually force it to fire or I would get more of a sillouette.All in all this is a great camera and I would not be afraid to use it on a pro job as well. It is that good of a camera!

Reviews.Title: G-15 A great camera
Reviews.Author: Thomas Adams
Reviews.Content: This camera does everything that Canon advertised.  It's easy to operate, functional, and takes super pictures in spite of the operator.  You can shoot HD video, bursts, single shots, you name it.  I really like the ease of functions, handling, weight, etc

Reviews.Title: G15
Reviews.Author: MK1
Reviews.Content: Looked at all the reviews but needed to feel the camera, once done ordered  and could not be happier.  Would recommend this to a friend

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Eddie Edmonds "Eddie E"
Reviews.Content: beautiful action pictures, portable and very strong body.I m not a professional obviously, but i do take plenty of pictures and I have had many cameras, this one has been the best one for me thus far.

Reviews.Title: Damn Good Camera
Reviews.Author: MATT
Reviews.Content: I am not a professional photographer, but I am a hobbyist. I like taking pictures a lot. I alwasy have my camera on me. I had the G11 for a few years now and I loved it. I skipped the G12 and upgraded to this camera. I wanted a compact pocketable camera that I can take everywhere. So far it has yet to displease me. It does all it is described to do and a bit more, and does it well. I know there are many reviews by the staunchest of camera buyers out there, but for the money... I don't think I would have bought anything else. So unless you are trying to become a pro photographer, and are just someone who likes to be able to take good pictures. This is the best bang for the buck in my opinion.

Reviews.Title: An upgrade from 16MP G10?
Reviews.Author: R. Poe "word jazz"
Reviews.Content: You bet!  Better lens, better processor, better low-light performance.  I enjoyed using the G10, and that fun-factor is still a winner for the G15.  I tried the G X1, but I failed to bond with that camera.  I loved the image quality, but the G15 is just as sharp, and simpler to use.  A good fit.

Reviews.Title: Awesome
Reviews.Author: Brandon Carpenter
Reviews.Content: Love this camera. It takes professional looking photos even with an amateur taking the photos. I have taken most of my photos on the auto setting, but I am really looking forward to learning how to take photos in the other settings. I am seriously contemplating taking a class to get the most out of this camera.

Reviews.Title: Great point and shoot
Reviews.Author: George Buettner "georgeb33"
Reviews.Content: Though I miss the articulating viewer of the G-11/12, this camera is spunky and takes beautiful shots...scenic, people, etc.It is solidly built, very light and the controls are typical Canon.  I have had 5 of the G series cameras, and cannot recommendthem highly enough for the traveler who wants to get those quality shots yet not haul around lots of heavy equipment.  I can keep this at my belt line in the little zip cases...readily available for that special picture.  This camera is quality all the way.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic quality.
Reviews.Author: Kitch Walker
Reviews.Content: Great Camera. Fantastic quality. Took it to Paris, France on vacation and never regretted it! Make sure to buy an extra battery so you never miss a shot!

Reviews.Title: Excellent Camera with Selectible Conrols for the Front and Rear Dials
Reviews.Author: AgingBoomer
Reviews.Content: My first digital camera after my film SLR days was the Canon G3. In my quest for ever smaller but highly adjustable cameras I next switched to Canon's S95.  My S95 works well and I like it a lot, but I have missed the larger in-hand size of the G series. The new G15 offers a greater focal length range, a much faster lens for higher low-light shutter speeds, and slightly better image quality.One feature I thought I was going to miss is the S95's step zoom control using the front lens ring.  Although the G15 does not have this control, it does allow you to choose among several control roles for the front dial (I chose white balance) and the rear control dial.  I chose step zoom for the rear dial and it is even more convenient than the front lens ring control on the S95. I had not noticed the G15's front and rear dial control selectibility in the various on-line reviews and I was very pleased to find it on the camera!

Reviews.Title: A minor downside...
Reviews.Author: L. Da Vinci "Renaissance Man"
Reviews.Content: After much research in different the photo websites and reading Consumer Reports, I decided to get this Canon G15. I have only had it a few days and I am very satisfied with it. So far, the only negative about this rugged little camera is how easily you can press the movie record button by accident. This red button is right next to the spot where you place your right thumb when you are shooting. It is not a major problem, just a little annoying, and I do not know how to avoid it.I wanted to expand my shooting with this camera, so I purchased the filter adapter for the lens, and I now can use regular 58mm filters (B & W my favorite): a UV filter as permanent lens protection, a Polarizer to remove glare and deepen colors, a neutral density filter for those very bright days when you need less light coming in. The camera's smallest opening is f. 8.0, so this is a limitation when you are photographing in a bright background.I used to be a professional photographer, using Hasselblads (in the old days), and Canon full frame cameras, so I am very particular when it comes to camera quality and features. One of my favorites features is the HRD mode, where the camera takes three pictures at different exposures and combines them all to come up with an exposure that will handle the highlights and the shadows. I can do that in a more professional fashion with Photoshop, but doing it this way is a lot easier and quicker than getting home and manipulating three different frames into one.Camera Pro's:Compact size, large f. 1.8 lens, a rugged build, very sharp LCD, large number of choices for special effects, very good movie mode, a good value.Camera negatives:Video mode goes on too easily, would like a larger zoom ratio, an articulating LCD would have been nice, as well as a time-lapse feature, like some Sony NEX models have.I will update this review as I use this camera more.CIAO!

Reviews.Title: Good quality for the price
Reviews.Author: MK "mk13books"
Reviews.Content: I absolutely adore my little camera. It feels very solid; the exterior is not a smooth finish, which I actually like. I feel like I get a better grip. The pics are comparable to Canon Rebel DSLRs with similar sensor sizes, although it doesn't come close to full-size sensor DSLRs. This is a great camera for traveling. I've given up on hauling my DSLR to Europe. I can enjoy my trip out whip out this little number when a photo op arises. I have a smaller PowerShot that is super lightweight, but for the few extra ounces, this one wins.

Reviews.Title: Awesome!
Reviews.Author: Willis E. Finch
Reviews.Content: This camera is so much better than the smaller point and shoots.  It is able to shoot in most low light situations without the aid of the flash.  Night photography is now a possibility!  The video function is easy to access and it takes great videos.  I love being able to adjust f-stops and shutter speed.  I can finally be creative with shots and am really enjoying this freedom.When you have this camera in your hands it feels like you have something.  Such a contrast to the cheap plastic point and shoots that are otherwise available.Very pleased with this product.

Reviews.Title: great camera- I have used the G12 for years and have loved it.  This is one of the best small cameras for travel.
Reviews.Author: peggy k mcintosh
Reviews.Content: I travel with a large Nikon and a Canon G12, but I am looking forward to traveling with the G15 and hope that I get great photos.

Reviews.Title: Great pocket camera!
Reviews.Author: John J. Prince
Reviews.Content: This was a replacement for another Canon pocket camera, so I had done a lot of research!  The lens is great the size is great, the imagery is superb!  You can read all the technical reviews on this product and see that is it is another great camera in the Canon point and shoot line.Menus, very clean and logical.Display bright and visible from multiple angles.Lens is superb!

Reviews.Title: Research paid off  :-)
Reviews.Author: cafc66
Reviews.Content: I had done a lot of research, especially at dpreview.com, for small cameras with superior quality (for the record, I own a Nikon D7000 body with an 18-200 lens and a couple of primes, so no newbie to photo).  This camera delivers outstanding photos for its size, in all kinds of lights. It's also very solidly built, and it comes with plenty of options for manual control.

Reviews.Title: Awesome camera!!
Reviews.Author: Lynn E. Oneill "LynnO"
Reviews.Content: The macro mode on this camera is fantastic!  Photos are crisp and clear, and the white balance is spot on. I have not had a chance to test all of the features yet, but the Auto, P, and AV modes produce high quality photos. I look forward to experimenting with other settings. I have had many Canon point-and-shot cameras and I have enjoyed, but this one exceeds my expectations. It has more features and options. I wish it came with the pocket-sized manual that used to come with Canon cameras. I'd pay extra for that. It's on CD, but that's not helpful if your on vacation and have a question.

Reviews.Title: Best camera for it's size
Reviews.Author: MODist
Reviews.Content: I have a Canon EOS 2TI that I love and use the canon 24mm-70mm L lens.  Love the pictures it takes but when traveling it is simply too much to carry.  With this camera I can leave the big beast at home and still get great shots, even in low light.  It's also much better at taking videos.

Reviews.Title: G15 exceeds expectations
Reviews.Author: Sharon Fink Stoltzfus
Reviews.Content: I do quite a bit of photography as an advanced, but not professional, photographer. I have used point-and-shoot digital cameras in the past, moved to a Nikon D70, followed by a Nikon D200. As many others have reported, at times it's just not convenient to carry 30 lbs of gear, but you never want to be without a camera. Add to that some early stages of arthritis in my hands, it was time to purchase something lighter and less cumbersome. As I conducted my research, I couldn't imagine a point-and-shoot camera would meet my needs, but I was impressed by the features and reviews of this camera so I decided to make the investment. I'm writing today to say it was well worth it! I've only had it for two weeks, and I am so impressed with this camera! First - remember the shutter lag with point and shoots? Not here! That was a major concern. One of the reviews I read indicated that if you took it out of facial recognition mode, it would shoot faster, so I did that right away. While it has an "auto" mode, I shoot primarily in "P" or "Tv (shutter priority)" and find the exposure evaluation to be incredible, even in low light (thanks to a very fast lens!). It has 5X digital zoom, and, even when I have gone into the first two levels of optical zoom, I haven't seen any degrading of the images. Because of the excellent exposure evaluation, about the only post-processing I do in Lightroom is crop (I shoot in both RAW and jpeg).  Having used Nikon for all these years, I was surprised at how quickly I adapted to the controls and features - it's very intuitively-created and user-friendly. I also appreciate some of the more "professional" options such as RAW, continuous shooting, a 2.8 lens, ISO starting at 80, frequently-used settings available outside the "Menu" feature, etc. It's comfortable to hold (unlike my smart phone, which has been my point-and-shoot for the past year), the image stabilization feature works nicely, and I really appreciate the fact that while one is shooting movies, you can zoom in or out during the process. The only drawback I have found is that while it shoots quickly, there is a pause while it saves the image and will not shoot until that has completed. I have turned the Review feature off and think that it may be my card as much as the camera itself, and the fact that I am shooting either in RAW or in the highest resolution of jpeg. It has a continuous shoot feature, though, that I use in settings where I need shots quickly.  In spite of that, I still give this 5 stars, because, after all, it's an incredible camera in its class. If I know I'm going to be in action settings where I need incredibly fast picture-taking capabilities, I need to use my D200. Other than that, it certainly holds its own against my D200, and I highly recommend making the investment in this camera.

Reviews.Title: Fast response, better specs and portable. Exellent
Reviews.Author: Akinlade
Reviews.Content: As a former user of G7 and G9 (bought from Amazon) and lately Lumix ZS20 (bought from Amazon) - all great cameras, I found the G15 a fantastic upgrade. It is as sturdy and well built as my previous two PowerShot models. For a start, the layout of the menus and the functions are more intuitive. I was able to quickly follow up and get to grips with using them. The response time is noticeably faster and the machine quickly focuses on the subject at hand once your hand is on the shutter release. The on camera stitch assist is very effective even though the stitch software is the 2008 version. Good macro function and good focussing under low lighting conditions.I am still trying my hand on it and so far I am satisfied.

Reviews.Title: Really good camera
Reviews.Author: Isaac
Reviews.Content: I just got this camera and took about 500 photos since , this is a really good camera, good quality built i couldn't ask for more it has so many customization options for pictures and the picture quality is really good, another fact to mention is that pictures with low light are really good , i totally recommend this camera

Reviews.Title: Muy buen producto
Reviews.Author: Fabio
Reviews.Content: Tal como lo esperaba! Una camara robusta, muy buen lente, liviana, con caracteristicas de semiprofesional, pantalla led grande y muy buen procesador para enfocar y toma fotos rapidamnte y de excelente calidad.La recomiendo

Reviews.Title: EVERYTHING ABOUT IT IS PERFECT
Reviews.Author: Nick
Reviews.Content: I got this camera for my mom who wanted a small camera with an eyepiece that took good pictures, and we found that and more in this amazing camera!

Reviews.Title: I am very happy with this camera.
Reviews.Author: R. Sessums
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera and I am happy that I bought it. I found the original G1 camera and have watched this camera developed over the years. The pictures are very clear. The controls are fairly standard for a Canon camera and are very easy and intuitive for me to use. The pictures have been great.I have only two small complaints about the camera. The first one is that the raw format that this camera produces is not supported in the popular picture software Picasa.  That is Picasa's fault however and hopefully they will develop support for it soon.My other complaint is that the flash has to be manually activated. This is not very hard to do and a fairly minor issue however. I guess that's a good part of this as that it increases the users controlling  flash .I would certainly recommend this camera to anybody who is looking for one in this class. Overall I am very happy with it.

Reviews.Title: Highly-rated compact camera for advanced amateurs
Reviews.Author: J. D. Morgan
Reviews.Content: A fast lens and relatively large sensor combine to give this camera good low-light sensitivity.  Controls range from fully-automatic to fully-manual. This camera also has a zooming viewfinder, making it much easier to capture action shots. The high-resolution viewscreen on the back of this camera is fixed -- it does not tilt and articulate like the one on the Canon G1X. However, this results in a slightly thinner and more-reliable design, and is actually the reason that I didn't buy the G1X last year.  The 12.1 Mpixel sensor may not be as large as some others, but it is entirely sufficient for all but poster-size prints.  This camera was given a rating of 9.8 on a scale of 10 by one camera-review site, coming very close to several $1000+ cameras.  I'd agree with that assessment.

Reviews.Title: Better than first thought
Reviews.Author: Joyce B. "Joyce B."
Reviews.Content: I was going to take this item back as I did not see the difference between the g15 and g12. However I took the camera on a cruise and discovered how well it performed when I returned and seemed to be doing less editing in my iPhoto. Either I'm getting better, or the camera was spot on. And I did not always use auto. I also used the video and was impressed by the videos I got when we were going through the Panama Canal. I feel like I'm back there it is so life like. I definitely would recommend the camera. Only once did I miss the articulated screen.

Reviews.Title: TAKES EXCELLENT PICTURES AND VIDEOS
Reviews.Author: C
Reviews.Content: The G15 is now a replacement for my Pentax Kr DSLR. The G15 does everything my DSLR does and then some. It has a very fast focus and plenty of manual setting for those who chose to use them.  I sometimes use manual settings, but have found the auto settings work quit well.  Pictures are excellent.  Even the digital zoom is good for small prints, which is all I do anyway.  I only print 5 x 7 or 3 x6 pictures.  The HD video is also great and looks good on the 922,000 dot LCD screen. I can even zoom while taking the video. If I ever have a time when I cannot see the LCD screen, I'll use the optical viewfinder (this hasn't happened yet). Since the optical viewfinder only shows 75% of the actual picture, it should be rarely used. The LCD works great anyway. I also agree with others that not carrying around the bulky DSLR is another benefit. I'm just an amateur photographer who likes taking good/great pictures and occasional movies.  The G15 does that for me.1/1/13  I finally tried the night shots using the scene mode setting.  They came out great.  I've also tried out the fisheye setting.  I'm not a particular fan of fisheye photo's, but it seems to work fine.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for when bulky is not an option
Reviews.Author: Craig D. Giffen
Reviews.Content: I have a Canon 7D that I use a ton, but on a recent vacation I took the G15 with me instead.  I didn't miss the 7D while travelling (nor its weight).Yes, I wish the video mode had a little more manual adjustment available while recording.  The only thing that really annoyed me about this camera was an issue I could fix myself...the camera strap!  The camera strap that comes with the camera takes up nearly as much space as the entire camera.

Reviews.Title: A Keeper
Reviews.Author: Go With Life
Reviews.Content: This is my 7th Canon Camera and is a total pleasure to use. Strong construction, a wealth of features, and great pictures. I will probably buy some more of these for my relatives.

Reviews.Title: Best camera EVER
Reviews.Author: Rachel Ramires de Lima
Reviews.Content: I was aiming the G12 or a Nikon 3100 when this one came, one month previous to my trip and changed all my plans.I am no photography pro, but loves photos and this was elected my entry level camera to start studying photography.It fits prefectly the hand,s but not to heavy. Honestly, I'd rather go for a lighter camera than with a one with articulated LCD.The sensor is amaziong. F/1.8 definetly makes a huge diiference, took amazing pictures in Vegas at night with no flash that were perfect. And the battery, amazing. more then 450 pictures, with LCD on and no flash,Indeed expensive, but worth every cent.

Reviews.Title: Surprise surprise
Reviews.Author: David L.
Reviews.Content: Was looking for a small portable camera when not convenient to carry the Nikon FX with large lenses.  I'm a dad who sometimes just wants to capture family activities but not pleased with the phone camera either.  I have heard good things about the Canon G-series with its built-in fast lens, build quality, vivid image colors, and friendly customer support.  Oh yea, it should be priced relatively close to the competitors, definitely under $700 and it would be nice to have a viewfinder.I chose the G15 because it meets my criteria above, but the additional attributes really sealed the deal.  They are:1. Great IS.  I no longer worry about minor hand shakes.2. Good low light performance.  Better than I expected from a smallish 1/1.7 inch sensor.  The amazing new sensor, fast 1.8-2.8 aperture, and legendary Canon image processing engine combine to do a fabulous job in all kinds of lighting but particularly dim light conditions.  The error free white balance and quick auto focus all perform well in varied situations.3.  The video.  Well exposed indoors and out.  Videos are focused, lots of depth of field, no shakes or wunky motions, and just generally forgiving when viewed on my 25 inch computer monitor.  Camera is so light that I don't get tired holding it for extended periods.  Maximum recording time is a generous 29 minutes per clip.  I also use video for kids sports, a great complement to the DSLR.4.  Great lens.  28-140mm at f1.8-2.8 is just phenominal in such packaging.  The fact that we can get 50-140mm at f2.8, that's unheard of in the past from a P&S.;  Macro is darn good too.  I often take pictures at close-ups (sorry, this includes food at restaurants!).  Lens is where in comparison, the G1x simply became non-competitive for me, despite the larger sensor which is highly attractive otherwise.  It is also an essential feature at weddings and on hikes when I run into exotic plants, flowers, and bugs.  A bonus:  the bokeh is way better than any compacts have any right to obtain.  When the subject is close, the background is thrown off...smoothly.  Not at the levels of dedicated DSLR macro lenses, but surprisingly good.5.  Ability to attach external flash.  Having an external flash for me really distinguishes a fine compact to an extraordinary one.  I use the Canon Speedlite 320EX which can bounce the flash up in 90 degrees in both landscape and portrait orientation, as well as having the video light.6.  Finally, the handling.  All the buttons and external dials are nice and quick in use.  The build quality using magnesium alloy is as awesome as all the reviewers say it is.  The feel spoils me.The features I'd love to see in the future G series are:1. Timelapse (already implemented in G16)2. Wide angle lens and Panorama mode3. Larger sensor while keeping the rest of the camera size at bayI find the G15 to be a trustworthy small camera to bring everywhere.  Highly recommend.

Reviews.Title: WOW.
Reviews.Author: William E. Liberatore
Reviews.Content: I've had an issue with point and shoots since I bought my first DSLR 5 years ago.  I don't always want to haul around the bigger body and the lenses, but I tend to feel disappointed when either I get pictures that I know could have been better or even worse, I can't get the picture and I know the DSLR could have.  I've found myself dreading the trade off of quality for convenience.  The G15 may well be the answer to that dilemma.  It is not a DSLR, but it can do some pretty amazing things for a point and shoot.  It has low light capability, an excellent auto-focus, and the ability to shoot RAW files.  All of this in a deceptively small frame.  The only complaints I've read so far are that it doesn't have a macro setting on the button at the top of the camera... for me this isn't an issue because if I'm going to do macro I'll probably use the DSLR anyway.  Also the view screen is not maneuverable.  I have one camera with a view screen that can tilt and twist and I pretty much never tilt or twist it.  I knew when I bought it that the screen was fixed and I'm ok with that.  If you buy this camera I hope that you are as pleased with it as I am and thanks for taking the time to read my review.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Lara B Weisberg
Reviews.Content: I am very pleased with this camera.  It takes great low light photos, something non of my previous cameras did (and I've owned other Canons before and other brands that claimed they took great low light photos.).  It's a little bigger than your average compact digital but worth it.  It takes very nice photos.  I love the viewfinder and the fact that you can take video with one push of a button on the back (it takes great video by the way).  You don't have to fiddle with any dials to enter video mode.  I don't mind the pop up flash at all (you have to manually put it up) because most times the camera can take a great picture even without the flash.  The camera has a solid feel to it.  Overall very please with this purchase.

Reviews.Title: Great Walk-around Camera when I don't need a DSLR
Reviews.Author: Timothy P. Lyons
Reviews.Content: I find the Canon G series to be the best of both worlds. Since the iPhone 4 came along, I have had no reason to carry a consumer grade point and shoot. However, when I need more features than the iPhone can provide, and don't want to carry the bulk of my EOS DSLR, the G15 bridges the gap between portability and performance.My G15 travels with me everywhere. The 5x optical zoom coupled with the ability to tweak most settings that you don't find on consumer grade cameras allow me to shoot nearly DSLR quality at a fraction of the price and size. The camera has traveled with me to Niagara Falls, several trips to Toronto, and St. Louis in the past two months and has yet to fail to impress.The autofocus is quick to focus on the subject and the camera can snap off several shots to ensure that I don't miss any action. I can pop the camera into auto mode to have a stranger take a portrait of myself in front of the falls, or I can shoot in my preferred aperture priority mode to have more control over the composition.Just like it's big brother DSLR, I find the pop-up flash to be equally worthless.I bought the camera primarily for underwater photography and it doesn't disappoint. With the WP-DC48 OEM housing, the camera can shoot underwater photos up to 40m depth with great clarity. I find the macro capabilities to be as impressive underwater, if not more so.Long story short, if you want most of the features of an SLR without the bulk, the G15 is the right camera for you.

Reviews.Title: Canon Powershot G15 12.1 MP Digital Camera
Reviews.Author: jdorqtrhorses
Reviews.Content: I'm not very good at reviewing items, but here goes.After debating between the Canon G15 and Nikon P7700 (which i tried first and returned) I got the G15.  I've had it for a little over a month now and have decided it's a keeper. Having been a Panasonic fan for years, I was a little disappointed in my last Pany camera (ZS15) and wanted something that shoots better in low light situations. I understand that these are two very different types of cameras.  So far this camera does an amazing job inside but due to the winter weather, I've not been able to get outside to shoot very much, but I've really liked the pictures I've gotten so far. I shoot mostly in Aperture, Shutter or P mode and since I've still got so much to learn about settings, I don't always get it right but I figure that's the only way I'm gonna learn. I also shoot jpeg & not raw.  Now the one thing I don't like about the camera is that it really blows out the highlights and I've not been able to figure out the right adjustments to compensate for that. Did read in other reviews that the camera has a problem with this.  The other thing is I'm having a heck of a time finding a case to fit it.  Just want something not to big, padded, that i can carry on my belt, with an extra battery & sd card.  I've bought 2 locally and both were to small so had to return them.  I guess I'm just going to have to take the camera with me when i go shopping for a case next time.  So if anyone reads this and has found the perfect case that it will fit into with the battery & sd card and can carry on your belt, would love to hear about it. So unless you are looking for a longer zoom and articulating back screen, which Canon did away with on the G15, I would highly recommend this camera.  The 4 star rating is due to the problem with blowing out the highlights.

Reviews.Title: G15 Great SLR point & shoot alternate
Reviews.Author: James J Cuff Jr
Reviews.Content: I recently purchased a point a shoot to bring with me ona trip to Maine. I knew it would outdoors and scenic and great weather in the summer. Lots of contrast. I did bring along my trusty Rebel XSI with Tamron 17-50 and 70-300 lens. But with so much on the go my rebel has been used less and less and only for specific events where I knew I was coming and going to and from home. Like kids events, photo shoot outing, sports, wedding. For the 90% of tother times I have been using my iphone 4s for most jobs. Recently on previous trip I lost many good shots with the iphone because the night photos were horrible. My friends had P&S; and all took great shots, low light, and in auto mode.My Rebel is great but other then daytime/dusk photos the lens ranges (for what I can afford) and the iso 1600 are limited for me. Many indoor shots are dark and I hate using a flash for point and shoot stuff or in sports where you can or too far. I wanted portable all day camera I can carry (little weight was ok just something I can pocket or small bag it over the SLR with no fear of breakage or getting stolen. And with little compromise to image quality. Plus I wanted video and some Bokeh.I bought a SX280 at first. But immediately returned it even after a firmware update the battery bug wouldn't go away. I was not going to risk having a faulty camera ruin my shots. After using the SX280 the zoom was great but like my other super zoom p&s; you loose speed and quality. It did take great pics for a P&S; and easy to carry and zoom and video were incredible. Photos clear. But zoom for bokeh, portraits and auto focus were little lacking. For most p&s; it was way better then anything I had seen. With the battery bug I returned and thought well what is next step up.After much research I loved the specs of the g15. I was concerned that the it was only a digic 5 not 6 over the sx280 and I would lose the speed and extra 720p slow mode modes and that the loss of zoom I would miss.After trying it out in best buy I could tell that the zoom even with digital was pretty capable and the 1-5x zoom seemed clear and sharper then the sx280 and looked like SLR on the screen.I traded it in and took hundred of photos in Maine and even did some compares with side by side of my SLR. I was impressed. All my fears were put aside. this is a great camera that has no flaws or irks during use. Sure there is some things i wish it would do a little better to make it an SLR but it isn't an SLR. Needless to say the pictures are SLR quality in some cases and in all cases being a p&s; it was more flexible then changing lenses without much loss or sacrifice for quality especially when you are going where you do not know what to expect (bring zoom, portrait,wide?)Pros:Body shape and feel is great grippy and solid rugged and looks goodButtons are easy to learn and great access to ISO,Aperture,F, in manual mode just like my slr (unlike the sx280 mind you) it was easy one hand thumb and taking pics easyScreen is awesome, I do not miss or need a touch screen. the navigation was similar to any canon and no issues. I prefer buttons up top anyway faster then looking at screen then refocus.Faster lens really helped. I traded the speed to keep the iso down and typically I could shoot under 80-160-320 iso all day and into dusk no problem and super clear low noise photos.In my compare the SLR stands out here and sharper images but this is only if you did side by side. the G15 photos are super crisp and vibrant and only in zoomed up details can you see softer edges compared to SLR.Zoom 5x was good for most shots and had great Bokeh for portraits at 1.8-2.2 range. Digital zoom worked better then I thought. You can shoot digital zoom and get nice uncropped photos for sure.Autofocus was fast, Much faster and accurate then my old rebelAWB: was accurate and better then my Rebel. I played a little with AWB but I found AWB worked in all my photos and was perfect night or day.Filters/Scenes. I rarely use the scenes but I found that since they are easily accessible from the knob they worked very well. the  filters were very fun and did a great job and made some great images. the toy,hdr,color swap were great.Colors: The Jpeg processor is spot on. Compared to edited raw photos the jpegs can be untouched IMHO. The RAW look real but flat at times (accurate) but for a P&S; the G5 had great color and pop. And the Color modes were great too. the Nostalgia and Super Vivid produced nice photos. Hybrid mode was pretty neat.Movies: WOW This thing takes great photos and zoomed in all the way to 20x with auto focus and allows use to set the color mode (super vivid for example) For videos alone this is a great HD camera. I had no problem recording 1-10min clips all day long and with no major battery drain. The sound was good too. There was some wind noise if windy but compared to the sx280 there is little lens auto focus noise. Only thing I could hear was me clicking the zoom back and fourth.Battery Life: No issues lasted for 2-3 days with all day use. And carry around was no problem. In my cargo pants pockets all day no issues or fear of losing or bulky.The interface was easy to learn and the display has some great options displaying all the info you need for the shots taken.ConsNot many but be nice to see:Movie mode has to be on in order to zoom past 5x.  Otherwise if you hit record in P mode say it only does optical up to 5xLens is great but only goes to F stop 8. I was hoping to crank it up. Not sure if this is a lens issue or hopefully could a hack later?Otherwise it is a great little camera and after using the SX280 I am glad I stayed with the G15. And I am going to sell my Rebel and wait for a new Digic 6 SLR body to use my lenses on.

Reviews.Title: Simple, Fast, Easy to Use
Reviews.Author: Pelicanpix
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera because I needed something that was easy to use, could easily fit in a purse or fanny pack without having a lens stick out, and had a viewfinder as well as an LCD view screen. I mainly use a camera as a hobby and taking pictures in my classroom. I needed a camera that I enjoyed using but other people could use as well without needing instructions. I brought this camera to school and asked a couple of people who work with me to take some pictures during a field trip. My previous camera had been difficult for other people to use and took too long between shots. After using the Canon G15 their comments were: It's so quick. It's so easy to use. I really like this. Wow! It's so simple. It's FAST! We all agreed that the camera was easy to take out of the bag, turn it on, take a picture (no lens cap to take on and off), and put back in the bag while still keeping a close, watchful eye on the students. Enough said.The Canon G15 is just slightly too large to fit comfortably in a pants pocket but it is small enough to easily fit in a coat pocket, small purse or fanny pack when traveling. No lens cap to worry about loosing. Ease of use, quality photos, and quick response time made the Canon G15 a winner for me.

Reviews.Title: All In One Camera You'll Ever Need
Reviews.Author: Girlruby "Ruby"
Reviews.Content: Let me tell you, i own different kinds of camera but when I saw this product. My search is over and I was completely sold out. The best camera I ever owned, the most compact and it gives you great pictures without even trying. I'm not a novice photographer nor a professional but when i take pictures with my G15. I feel like I'm one. It gives you great shots like a 35mm camera and the color quality is amazing. You have to buy it to believe it. Canon went to such great lenghts to make this camera as close to perpect in my opinion. I own a Canon Mark11 DSLR and a Canon T1i and this is as close as you can get with the G15 without carrying excess baggage. Its so small and portable. I recently use this when I went to a 13 day trip Turkey a month ago. My experience with this camera is priceless. Check it out for yourself.

Reviews.Title: A Good Camera For Enthusiasts
Reviews.Author: Darrin Robertson "BabylonSlim"
Reviews.Content: I'm a photography enthusiast. I wanted a point and shoot camera to eliminate of the risk and weight of lugging my DSLR everywhere. After reviewing several brands, my decision to buy this camera was partially influenced by that it is a Canon and compatible with some accessories I already own.That said...I'm enjoying it immensely. The creative filters and shooting modes are a lot of fun. A couple of the features really impressed me, specifically the ability to detect a blinking subject and the ability to replace a color in camera. Its auto modes handle exposure, focus, and white balance quite well.When you want manual control, you've got it. With the exception of Bulb exposure (the G15 doesn't have it), the manual controls are everything you need to take control of your photography.The camera itself is well made. The lens is fast and clear, burst mode is fast, and the controls are easily accessible. The metal body makes the camera feel solid in your hand. It's a bit too large to be considered pocketable, but not by very much.The viewfinder is a bit lacking. It doesn't have a focal point and it's very inaccurate at zoom. It's good for pointing the camera in the right direction in bright sunlight and that's about it.This camera meets my needs quite well. It's the point and shoot I can use in family and social situations and also small enough for me to take everywhere and capture creative photos of opportunity.If you're a Canon DSLR owner and need a point and shoot, I recommend it. I would also recommend this camera for somebody who wants to explore creative photography but doesn't want a DSLR.

Reviews.Title: problematic camera + lacking customer service
Reviews.Author: leo
Reviews.Content: i purchased the canon G15 in february 2013 and had to send it in for repairs twice within the first 10 months of having it.images in the viewfinder prior to taking photographs looked clear, crisp and sharp, but often looked unfocused after the picture was taken.  canon had me send it in for repairs after i let them know that i tested the camera in the following ways:1. cleaned the lens2. put the camera on a tripod to prevent the camera from shaking3. set the self timer to prevent the camera from shaking4. shot photos with all 3 focusing options ('evaluative', 'center weighted AVG' and 'spot') to ensure that the setting wasn't responsible for the unfocused shot5. tried shooting using the manual settingsa few months later there were other problems.  the camera was locking up.  at first the zoom, the function and the menu buttons were locking up.  it happened 3 times within 10 days.  i followed canon's recommendations to 1) remove the battery and the memory card, 2) clean the battery contacts with a lint-free cloth, 3) wait 20 minutes before inserting a fresh fully charged battery and 4) turn the camera on and put it in picture taking mode, but it did not help.  ultimately, the shutter locked up too, making the camera completely inoperable.  since the camera still didn't focus properly i asked canon if i could trade it in to purchase a higher quality camera.  they never responded.my canon G10 had problems too.  problems began with the zoom not functioning properly.  the camera also allowed dust particles to enter its supposed airtight body.  the dust appeared like dark blotches on the photographs.  ultimately, trying to use the camera with all of its shortcomings was too much of a hassle.  so i bought the G15...not the wisest choice.canon's customer service can also use help.  it'd be nice if they were more customer-centric - more sensitive and responsive to customer's needs and requests.  when i sent my camera in for repairs on december 10th i asked that it be returned to me as soon as possible...because i wanted to use it during the holidays.  i was not happy when i received it back on december 26th.  this and the fact that they never responded to whether i could trade the camera in towards the purchase of a higher quality camera irked me.additional issues:* i was unable to download movies from the G15 to my computer.  i had to purchase a separate memory card reader to do so.* the G15 user manual is digital, which is a hassle to use when there's a need to go back and forth through its 300 pages for information.  i ended up having to order a hardcopy of the manual separately.

Reviews.Title: Just what I was looking for!
Reviews.Author: Biomedman
Reviews.Content: I wanted something to take on trips so I didn't have to lug around my EOS and big, heavy lenses all the time. This G15 turned out to fit my needs nearly perfectly. I only wish it had a longer lens. I added the Mag Filter kit, which works great! Fully programmable, manual macro focus adjustments, etc. and the pics come out great! No, it doesn't fit in your pocket, but very few P&S; in this category will. I'm very pleased with the G15 purchase.

Reviews.Title: All the Right Camera Traits
Reviews.Author: Andi C Bair
Reviews.Content: Canon G15 does what it promises, and does it well. I have to admit, though, that many cameras by reputable makers (and there are many) deliver what they promise. It is more about what camera traits you are looking for. So, I would suggest to anyone looking to buy one to google 'camera trait search' and get the lay of the land.The G15 is a fixed lens camera (point and shoot, some would say), with 12.1 resolution (megapixels), and x5 zoom. Probably the most important point for this class of cameras is the sensor size, which is 1/1.7 inch CMOS-type. That is just a number, but one that matters. Most point and shoots have a 1/2.3 inch sensor, which is a couple of steps worse than the G15.It also has a viewfinder, which many don't. The ISO rating is 12,800 which makes it work better in low light. The video is a Full HD- that is 1980x1080 resolution. The camera gives you the option to control manually both the exposure and the focus. It does have an external flash option. That is a plus too, especially for portraits. The LCD screen has a 922,000 resolution, and the burst rate- for fast action- of 2.1 specified works fine. The camera also does RAW processing which would matter if you did not want to be limited by JPEG storage only. And all this with a fairly light camera weighing only 352 grams.Overall, great camera. Having been into photography for a while, I do stress though that you do a camera trait search. That will also tell you more about what you want.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Frederick C. Bucheit "derfbu"
Reviews.Content: So far, I really like this camera. I have had a dozen digital cameras in the past 10 years, and this one is excellent. I got tired of carrying around a large nikon or canon digital DSLR. I think this might be the answer to that dilemma. The pictures are excellent, and the options are plentiful.

Reviews.Title: bought it as a gift
Reviews.Author: matthew c.
Reviews.Content: For the price, hard to beat the performance of this little camera. great lens, not too difficult to pick up and figure out the use. Good pictures so far. Easy to carry. Did research before purchases as a gift.

Reviews.Title: So happy to be back to my Canon!
Reviews.Author: butters
Reviews.Content: I LOVE this camera. I owned the G9 and G12 as well. The G9 was WONDERFUL, but died after a couple years. It was too much to repair, so I bought the G12. I didn't feel like the G12 gave the same amazing quality images.... After a year, I sold it for $300 (Canon's hold their value - that's for sure) and I bought the crazy expensive super-hyped SONY RX-100. I ignored the bad reviews for the Sony and only listened to the hype. I was so disappointed. The Sony never once gave me a great picture - not one. It had serious focussing issues at near- and mid-distance. The color was always whacked, the images were always sad. These were the same problems that other people had, and I contacted Sony three different times - hoping they would fix my lemon. Every time they would just send me instructions on how to take a photo - as if I didn't know how to do it. Anyway, I had to live with the Sony for a long time - and I basically took pictures with my iPhone for that entire time.Enough about the Sony! I am so glad to be back to Canon - and the PowerShot G-series. The G15 is great. I love the image quality, the video capabilities, and the interface. I have no problem with the stationary screen, and I really like the textured surface.

Reviews.Title: Very competent solid performing  camera!
Reviews.Author: D. Crum "crumvoc"
Reviews.Content: I have had this camera now for 8 months and I really like it. Built like a tank. It takes very good photos, even in auto mode.  Lots of manual exposure/focus options.  Can create very nice HDR photos using three-shot bracketing.  The only downside for me is the lack of a long telephoto ability.  So, it's not a good "birding" camera.  However, I have taken some very nice landscape/architectural photos.  Since the G16 came out, the G15 is discounted around $100.  I have looked at the G16, and can't think of any solid reason to replace the G15 with it.  Same lens, same sensor.  the G16 apparently has a faster processor, but I've never felt "bogged down" by the G15.

Reviews.Title: Great travel camera!
Reviews.Author: Kevin H Milligan
Reviews.Content: Bought this as a gift for my daughter who used our G15 on her trip to Europe and loved the camera.  She was very pleased to get one of her own.  The G15 takes very nice pictures with a smaller footprint than the larger DSLR cameras, making it perfect for capturing pictures on the go.

Reviews.Title: I love this camera
Reviews.Author: Marino
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera for shooting indoors in low light. I love it much easier than my DSLR. The price was right at $350.00

Reviews.Title: Canon Powershot G15
Reviews.Author: Lin
Reviews.Content: This was a gift and I love the camera so far.  I have a Canon DSLR and wanted something smaller to carry for every day.  Love the size, the features, and weight of the camera.  It will be fun learning all the features of this camera.  Having been a Canon user for years makes it easier it jump right in with the G15.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for the money.
Reviews.Author: David C. Mcsloy
Reviews.Content: This camera has a fast 1.8 lens for low light shooting, a viewer for shooting in bright sunshine and a rugged metal case that reminds me of my Leica build quality for half the price.

Reviews.Title: This camera is a good buy at this time
Reviews.Author: bisjack
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera shortly after the G16 came out and the price was significantly reduced.  At the reduced price this camera was and is a steal.  I have a Canon G11 which I have liked  and used for those situations when a large DSLR is not convenient.  This camera with its 12 meg sensor and even better controls produces even better results with much lower noise at higher ISO's.I don't miss the articulated LCD screen since I have never used it a lot on the G11.  Most of the situations where I use this camera require that I use the eye level viewfinder because of ambient light. And surprisingly the ELV frames the picture pretty well.  Without the articulated screen, the camera just fits in my jeans pocket whereas the G11 with the articulated screen is just thick enough not to fit.At the current pricing, I am a real booster for this camera and would  highly recommend it as a first camera or as a backup for DSLR shooters.

Reviews.Title: Canon PowerShot G15
Reviews.Author: KEN TELLS ALL "Perfectionist"
Reviews.Content: Great compact camera. Took it on my 3 week ascension to the Land Of Israel. I took many great pictures and it was a pleasure to carry around. I did not want to haul around my regular T3i with all its lenses. This camera was all I needed.I recommend it highly!

Reviews.Title: A great Canon
Reviews.Author: Jack Mitchell
Reviews.Content: Canon was the camera of my choice, it just had to be a Canon and I'm so glad I purchased the G15, has all features I need and so easy to use.

Reviews.Title: Replacement
Reviews.Author: Cristi Cox
