Reviews.Content: II had this camera and use it for underwater photography, I unfortunately flooded it and needed to replace it.  So I knew what I wanted when I ordered it.  I am very happy.  If you like to do maunal setting this camera will let you do that.

Reviews.Title: almost DSLR quality but far more portable
Reviews.Author: aeb81
Reviews.Content: I debated saving for an entry level DSLR camera or going for a camera like this. I'm someone who has considered getting into photography as a hobby & wanted the right camera that's a step up from a point & shoot. What sold me on this camera over a DSLR is portability. A camera is useless if it stays in the closet. For its size it's very light weight. It would be far more practical for travel pics than a bigger camera.I was a bridesmaid recently & was able to slip this camera into my pocket (apparently bridesmaids dresses are sometimes made with pockets now!) for the wedding reception. I can't imagine lugging around a DSLR there without looking ridiculous. I was able to get some really great photos before the wedding when all the bridesmaids & bride were getting ready & at the reception. Most of the pictures were on auto mode as I wanted to not miss any moments & also to take pics quickly to get out of the way of the paid wedding photographers. Even in auto mode the pictures looked great.If you do not need a camera to take a lot of posed or still pictures, I would definitely recommend this camera over a DSLR for portability, & the picture quality is great.

Reviews.Title: An Excellent Value and Top sharp shooter
Reviews.Author: wirelessguy "wirelessguy"
Reviews.Content: I had to do some research for friends and family on dependable Sharp shooting pocketable cameras and had two people buy the G15.  When I found myself needing to update a compact camera recently this was the unit I chose for myself. Facial recognition is also a good way toensure that multiple parties all remain in focusCompact cameras have come a very long way and in all honesty I wish the DSLRs would make more effort to have their auto-settings lean toward "all-in-focus" rather than their default low aperture and shallow depth of field.Great job Canon.

Reviews.Title: Buy it if you want a sharp lens at a reasonable price.
Reviews.Author: AR LV Shopper
Reviews.Content: Value camera with an exceptional sharp lens. Every dial and adjustment in right on your finger tip. Would recommend it to anyone.

Reviews.Title: Great camera.  Worth every penny if you can wait for a price drop.
Reviews.Author: A. Stuber
Reviews.Content: For the money, this is a lot of camera.  Well built with a solid body.  Images come out really sharp.  In well lit compositions, it is hard for me to tell the difference between photos taken with my DSLR and those taken with the G15.  Price fluctuates a lot on amazon.  In one week, I have seen it go from $450 to $300 to $400 then back to $350.  If you can get it at $300-$350, it is a steal.

Reviews.Title: Excellent inexpensive option for underwater photography
Reviews.Author: pdub
Reviews.Content: I'll keep my review short as other have already done a great job explaining the features and technical specs of the Canon G15. I bought mine to bring on a dive trip. My previous UW camera was a Canon Powershot SD940 IS in a Canon housing which yielded excellent photos and video, but had awful battery life. I knew that the G15 could last several dives in a row on one charge, while providing the trusted Canon quality.Instead of buying the Canon branded UW housing, I went with one from MegaGear (cost a lot less, came with threads for underwater closeup lens). With this housing, two Fantasea Sharp Eye underwater closeup lenses and a Sola Dive Light (800 lumens with hand strap), I was able to take some great shots (uploaded a few as examples of what's possible). The camera performed without any glitches and I'm very happy with my purchase.I also took some photos while on land and was pleased with the quality. I didn't experience any issues with overexposure as mentioned by other reviewers. Overall, the G15 did a splendid job throughout my recent month-long trip to Kuala Lumpur (with 10 days on the side to Indonesia for my dives). I'd recommend this to anyone looking for a solid travel camera and definitely to any amateur underwater photographer wanting to get some good photos without a bulky, expensive kit.

Reviews.Title: Perfect size and power.
Reviews.Author: Benjamin Ahn
Reviews.Content: I have owned several high powered digital cameras including the Canon 1D, 30D, and the Lumix GH2 and the G15 is the best combination of size and power that I need.The thing with DSLR's is that you end up not taking them everywhere and because of that, I found myself using my iphone for pictures and video all the time.  The G15 is not as small as some of the point and shoot out there but, for me, it gives me the DSLR look in pictures that others don't specially because of the F2.8 lens and RAW capability.  Another pleasant surprise was it's video capabilities.  It creates wonderfully warm and sharp videos that definitely differ themselves from cell phone videos.If you need to find a good compromise between a DSLR and your cell phone, this is it.

Reviews.Title: In for repairs
Reviews.Author: Charles
Reviews.Content: My G15 is an upgrade from the G9.  Both are excellent cameras and the improvements of the G15 are sufficient to justify buying it.  However, both my G9 and my G15 have gone to Canon service.  The G9--out of warranty--just quit working while I was on a trip.  The G15, less than a year old, has the problem with the lens extending only part way.  The Canon people are very nice, but I do not like being without my camera for two or three weeks.  I do not know if my cameras are the exception or if I am just unlucky.  Or, does Canon have a quality control issue.  That is why I gave it 4 stars.  When it is working, it is a great camera.

Reviews.Title: Old Man,  New Camera
Reviews.Author: Nubber
Reviews.Content: Now that I have had this camera for about 3 months, I can truthfully say, it is the best camera I ever owned.  I have had some cameras that I have taken  good pictures with, but never a camera that I get consistently good pictures ever time.  For the person that is not a professional, but wants a professional picture, this is the camera for you.  I take pictures of the grand-kids birthdays, football games, cheering, soccer, swimming.  You name it, if it involves my family, I take pictures.  The video with this camera is even better than my dedicated video camera.  It took a few weeks for the learning curve on this camera, but worth every minute I spent with it.  The G15 takes wonderful pictures out doors, and the indoor shots are better than most.  The color reproduction with the flash can get a little off, but with a good photo program, you can compensate for this.  Would I recommend this camera to friends,  Yes ! and I already have.

Reviews.Title: Great compact camera as backup to my DSLR.
Reviews.Author: Jennifer L Vater
Reviews.Content: My wife and I often want two cameras so that we can both take pictures when we're apart.  We had two DSLRs until one failed beyond repair.  We got by without a second camera for a year.  Then our telephoto lens failed on the remaining DSLR one week before a long trip.  We decided that a compact camera would be a good complement to our DSLR once the lens was repaired.  I was quite worried that I would find the image quality sub-par compared to our DSLR, but we purchased the G15 thinking we could function as closely as possible to our Canon DSLRs.  I am very pleased with the results of my first 1000 pictures.  It actually performs better than my DSLR in low light (my newest DSLR is probably six years old).  Great compact camera with the controls of a DSLR.

Reviews.Title: A Winner !!
Reviews.Author: Brooksider
Reviews.Content: This is my 4th Canon camera.  I use it for work related pictures when I travel.  It takes great pictures.  Nice compact size.  Lots of easy to use features.  I'm particularly impressed with the quality of pictures it takes under low light conditions & close-ups.I strongly recommend this camera for any serious photographer.

Reviews.Title: Nice camera.
Reviews.Author: Leo Gutkin "Lelik"
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera for my trip to Europe. Nice, crispy pictures and great video. I think my camcorder just has been fired, one less thing to pack when travelling. I still need to learn a lot of great features this camera has to offer.

Reviews.Title: Amazingly powerful
Reviews.Author: Silversmith "jimbove"
Reviews.Content: We take a lot of photos, both for work and for pleasure.  After a good bit of research and knowing what we were looking for, low light capable, good video, great macro, image quality and versatile, we decided to go with the G15.  I am frankly amazed at what we were able to get for this price range.  This camera is a monster. It has features that I didn't even know I wanted.  I love the C1 and C2 custom settings. In our studio I just set up a custom light setting and programed my shot under C1 and I have never had to readjust the white balance.  Some of the objects I shoot, white on white, are very hard for a camera to read, this one I just switch to manual focus and no problem. outdoor shots, low light, zoom, video, it does it all well.  Battery life is amazing. Even using the flash just to test its limits, the camera keeps going.Previous cameras: Lumix (never again.  Quality went down so much), Canon Rebel and Canon D7

Reviews.Title: Fabulous camera!
Reviews.Author: Lynne
Reviews.Content: This is a fabulous camera!  It was shipped very quickly. The camera is light and takes amazing pictures.  I normally use an SLR camera--I find this little baby takes pictures as well and in some cases, even better than my SLR.  It has amazing functionality and is very intuitive.  Highly Recommend!

Reviews.Title: Perfect go anywhere camera.
Reviews.Author: Veepeeple
Reviews.Content: Great little camera with amazing capabilities. Not the lightest thing to have around your neck all day though. Love it.

Reviews.Title: Perfect in almost every way!
Reviews.Author: bradenbru
Reviews.Content: Excellent feel, weight and grip. Image quality is superb, and even fairly novice photographers can take excellent shots. Analog viewfinder works well enough. Definitely worth your consideration.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Jean L.
Reviews.Content: I am very happy with my new camera.  I especially like how I can take excellent close-up shots of flowers outside.  Have not used as much inside but did take a very clear video clip with motion in it.

Reviews.Title: Powerful Small Camera with Raw Shooting Capability
Reviews.Author: Pedro
Reviews.Content: This little camera packs a powerful imaging capability with excellent lens, a mix of wide to telephoto, and the F1.8 to 2.8 aperture which makes low light photography possible. You cannot go wrong with this camera in those instances in which taking a larger DSLR and lens on a trip is not a prudent choice for weight or security reasons. I have had this camera for a few months and have taken several thousand photographs in a variety of light conditions. the images are superb when shooting in raw mode followed by post photo processing.  A highly recommend this camera as a travel camera for professional photographers.

Reviews.Title: Months later, and no need for more.
Reviews.Author: Randy Browning
Reviews.Content: I have now had this camera for seven months, and I continue to be amazed at the picture quality, almost as much as I am by the 1 & 2 star reviews. If you can't figure out how to open the box, you should not write a review on a complex advanced digital camera. Yes, you can set it and forget it in the Auto mode, and it will produce fantastic results, but when you start to stretch it's legs, you will not find many cameras +/- $200 that will produce the same vivid colors with the same depth of field as this Canon offering. So far I've had it in San Antonio TX, Aptos CA, Panama City FL, and Salt Lake City UT. Each location shines for its variety of photographic opportunities. For landscape and architectural captures I actually do prefer the Smart Auto. I have operated it myself taking advantage of the SP and AP options, but I have seldom been able to produce results better than the smart auto.For portrats the Portrait sceen mode does a more than acceptable job, but the auto features will be appreciated.If you want a good in between camera, and don't mind a smaller lens zoom, this camera will make a good companion.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera
Reviews.Author: Almost Sixty!
Reviews.Content: I had a Canon Elf, but missed the better zoom lens. This satisfies my need for a great point and shoot camera, with additional features found in larger and more expensive cameras.

Reviews.Title: Just what she was looking for..
Reviews.Author: P. Bostley
Reviews.Content: This was a birthday present for my wife.  It takes good pictures and is easy to use. It has some interesting features like smile recognition.  The G series definitely fills the hole between my big SLR and the crappy camera in our phones.

Reviews.Title: A lot smaller than I expected
Reviews.Author: Fred Stone
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera as a replacement for a Sony NEX-5 (first model) which just did not fit my needs.  I had previously owned a number of digital cameras, mostly Canons, going back to the first Digital Elph S100.  This camera fits the hand perfectly and i auto mode takes excellent pictures.  I took it on a trip to Europe and took over 700 pictures under all lighting conditions to include night in the rain in Venice.  It performed extremely well.  Although it has a viewfinder, I found the screen to be bright enough in strong daylight to use without a problem, a concern that I had with the Sony.  I am very pleased with this camera.

Reviews.Title: Love the image quality
Reviews.Author: AlmaM
Reviews.Content: I love this camera. Photos are so clear and great quality.Video is great even under low light conditions.Ideal if you don't want to carry a big REFLEX when travelling, this camera will let you be creative and take great pictures.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Camera
Reviews.Author: W. Whicker "AW"
Reviews.Content: It's hard to think of anything to add to the other reviews here. The camera is wonderful. Having the dials makes it easy to manually change settings, such as with Aperture Priority. With the fast lens, the camera tends to favor larger apertures, so when I want to stop down I use AV or M settings and change the aperture to get more sharpness. I love that it shoots RAW and/or JPG, and the 1080p video is breath-taking.The monitor is very crisp and a joy to view in most lighting situations (brightness can be adjusted, too). All of the controls are intuitive and easy to use, as are the menus, especially if you've used Canon cameras before. The body feels sturdy and the non-slip finish is very effective.The only issue I've had so far is noticeable barrel distortion at wide angles, such as with cityscapes or architecture. Its not so noticeable with nature or portraits, and does fall off the more you zoom in.Battery life is fine, and the hot shoe works well with my Canon 430ex flash (though the flash is huge compared to the camera). Another note; I have a great little lens adapter tube attached to the camera, with a Sigma multi-coated 58mm UV filter. I like how this setup adds to the size of the camera (easier to hold in various ways), and it protects the lens. I just bumped it today walking through a crowded location, and didn't worry - only the edge of the filter was hit, and though light, it was nice to know it was an easily replaceable part and not the lens itself. Amazon has great prices on Canon and off-brand version of these.Over all, I definitely recommend this camera - I've found it a perfect carry-around piece. While it's still doesn't have all the features I love in my DSLR, it makes up for the difference in size, weight, and versatility. A great buy.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Denise Wylie
Reviews.Content: I love this G-15.  So happy I bought it. Takes beautiful pictures, easy to use. Would definitely recommend it to anyone.

Reviews.Title: Extremely fast focus and faster lens
Reviews.Author: Michael Weingartner
Reviews.Content: I was one of Canon's customers who preferred the older G series that was thinner thanks to the non-pivot back screen.  Going back to this format and reducing the size of the camera was a win for me.My primary uses for the G15 are as an everyday shooter and for macro photography.  I am an enthusiast, not a professional.  The camera excels in both situations.  You get full creative control of your shot with a relatively small camera.  If you are a Canon user then the control scheme is just what you would expect.This is an excellent camera for someone wanting raw format, fast focus, excellent low-light support, and high quality construction. The final product feels color accurate to me as well.  Overall a great product.

Reviews.Title: Wonderful!
Reviews.Author: Matthew Ferrara
Reviews.Content: This camera is so good, I might buy a second to just bang around with when I don't want to carry my Nikon D7000 full DSLR with me. Takes great shots in all light conditions and very easy to use. Nice features built right in. Overall an amazing camera for the price - you won't be disappointed!

Reviews.Title: new favorite every day camera for the semipro
Reviews.Author: alisa
Reviews.Content: excellent lens quality, comparable to the photographic qualities of my canon 7D! All the right features, good weight in your hand, this is my favorite canon camera ever!

Reviews.Title: The G12
Reviews.Author: Frank
Reviews.Content: Small, light and snappy performance. Not to mention excellent image quality. I've used the G10 and G12 before it and the G15 is clearly the best so far. Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: Exceptional Camera
Reviews.Author: sam parrino
Reviews.Content: I was looking for a quality camera in this price range and the G15 fits nicely. Many features and still compact. I also liked the fact that a very nice leather case was also availble. I particularly like it's retro style.

Reviews.Title: Built to last.
Reviews.Author: Richard C Grinstead II
Reviews.Content: Almost a "Rebel" but in a smaller package. Advanced brain. You won't regret the advanced pictures you will see when you look at them later.

Reviews.Title: Great Product
Reviews.Author: German
Reviews.Content: Amazing product. Very easy to use.The movies i make are realy good because of its stabilize sistem. You dont need to buy another camera. Record video in stereo sound.

Reviews.Title: My Upgrade to my G11
Reviews.Author: V. V. Burns "Ja  Mata"
Reviews.Content: My G11 ended up with a scratch on the lens so I was leaving in a trip and ordered up one of these.Suffice to say I love it!PROS:Faster than the G11 [Lens (2.8) / Focus / Shutter]Superior lower light capability - Compared to the G11 that stretches the capability too far - the G15 is really impressive.ComplicatedSlightly better flash or at least sensor sensitivityCONS:No back LCD screen.  I used it a lot on my G11 to take 'perspective' shots without have to kneel or lay down etc.ComplicatedThe flash is manually activated / opened - sometimes you forget!The one feature I would always like to have is a quick "fill flash" option - even in "Auto" mode - so many times I have to rotate to my "Program" feature where I have it pre-set up fill flash.All in all an unbelievable camera in the Sub $500 range.If you have a G11/G12 its worth the upgrade!!!

Reviews.Title: Canon G15
Reviews.Author: James A. Sterr
Reviews.Content: I was looking for a smaller camera that takes good pictures.This one fills the bill. My wife can use the auto setting and get great pictures.Plus there are many manual settings for experimenting.Good investment.

Reviews.Author: Marigi Barragan
Reviews.Content: Over my expectations! Everything that could have a professional one in a compact camera. Great photos, great experience! Highly Recomended!

Reviews.Title: Canon G15
Reviews.Author: Tarek Abdel Monem Taha
Reviews.Content: The Canon G15 received on time with no delay at all ,,, we are very happy from it ,, it was as described on the sales and the quality of photos are very good and much better from older models.

Reviews.Title: Awesome camera
Reviews.Author: Mary S. Martin
Reviews.Content: Picture quality is outstanding. So glad I went with the G-15. I have taken some pictures that came out better than a friend's pics who has a Rebel!!

Reviews.Title: Excellent compact camera for photo enthusiast
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera to use on a Panama Canal cruise we are taking in April. I have a Sony Nex 5N with telephoto lens but I wanted something more compact for this trip. I received the camera yesterday and went out to test it today against the Sony. I was pleasantly surprised. It comes very close to replacing the Sony. It is easy to handle, feels extremely comfortable in your hand, focuses relatively fast, built like a brick, has all the manual features that anyone needs and feels like a professional compact cmera should. All I need is a polarizing filter and I'll be all set for the trip. A great camera and very pleased again with Amazon's fulfillment department!!!!!!!

Reviews.Title: best canon G series to date
Reviews.Author: steve f
Reviews.Content: the lens is fantastic on this camera, i have owned a couple powershots over the years and this one is the best. Yes i miss the articulating screen, but it is worth the sacrifice. you wont be sorry with this purchase.

Reviews.Title: The perfect small camera
Reviews.Author: RLM "RLM"
Reviews.Content: I have been searching for an alternative to my pro DSLR gear for times when I just don't want to lug around heavy, expensive equipment (e.g.. skiing, hiking, trips to Disney, family candids, etc). I've tried the Sony NEX 7 and NEX 6 as well as m43 systems. Invariably these systems proved to be less compact than I expected. I also found lens options to be very limited. I've used Canon's S95 and S100 and was very impressed with image quality (considering the size) but ultimately found usability to be problematic. The Canon G15 is a fantastic solution. The controls are laid out very clearly. The lens fast at both wide and tele. The lens retractable and with a built in lens cover. The camera is built like a tank - very well made - and a pleasure to use. While it won't fit in your jeans pocket, it will easily fit in a jacket pocket. Or you can simply hang it around your neck and forget it is there.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic
Reviews.Author: T. M. Truax
Reviews.Content: This unit replaces my Canon Powershot G7 which served me well for years. I hesitated in upgrading the G7 for years because the improvement margin just didn't justify the expenditure. The G15's video quality is amazing and the photos remain excellent in this model. I have a Nikon D-5100 and love it, but this fills the bill for a quality "little bother" to take along for lighter trips. There are enough advanced/manual shooting adjustments to satisfy serious DSLR photographers when they can't, or don't want to lug all their DSLR equipment with them.

Reviews.Title: Fast, Great photo's, vivid colours
Reviews.Author: Alan Rafferty
Reviews.Content: I've had a couple of different pro-sumer cameras over the years and this is the best so far, the camera is quick, the view finder is useful when taking photo's of far off objects or scenic shots, the rear screen is bright and clear. A buddy has the Nikon version but it's a little big for me, I did try the Sony but didn't like the feel or ergonomics. This is a great camera, you won't be disappointed

Reviews.Title: The Goldilocks of Cameras
Reviews.Author: Curtis H. Jacobsen
Reviews.Content: I love this camera. It is just the right size. Not too big, and not too small. I got this camera for an upcoming trip to Europe and don't want to lug around a heavy SLR with all the extra lenses and accessories. And some other models, like the Canon S110 or the Sony RX100, are just too small for my large hands. This camera is a great compromise. I've been using it around town to learn all the features before my trip and so far it is living up to the great reviews. The pictures are sharp, the colors are excellent, the camera is quick and responsive. I'd love to hear from any pros out there suggestions on how to set up the custom modes, C1 and C2, for my trip. I'll be going to the Swiss Alps as well as Lake Como and Paris. I'd like one setting for the vast landscapes of the Alps and a second for shooting interiors, like churches and museums.

Reviews.Title: The G15 is a lot of camera
Reviews.Author: cbHoo
Reviews.Content: Only had it a month so far but I am very impressed.  This camera has excellent picture quality and unlimited manual adjustments for those so inclined.  I have not yet had a chance to use in low light and that was one of the big draws for me but I am pleased with the outdoor pictures in sunny and very cloudy light.  Very crisp detail.  It has a solid feel in the hand - it is not a pocket camera although it is not so bulky that it is a pain to carry.  A perfect alternative for those of us who don't want to carry a bulky/heavy DSLR but want much more control/quality than the simple point and shoot.  A little more zoom would have been nice but with the shoot quality it is easy enough to crop the image to zoom in.  The non-articulating screen is no big deal to me like it is to some of the other reviewers.  I had it on another Canon but did not use it much (and it added bulky size to the camera which I don't want).  I like the viewfinder outdoors because it is easier to use than the LCD in the sun - only wish some of the status info was visible in the viewfinder like earlier Canon cameras.  All in all, I am very pleased with my G15 and would buy it again.

Reviews.Title: A 'Real' Camera in a Convenient Sized Package
Reviews.Author: gzvidz
Reviews.Content: The new category of cameras that active people are interested in is compacts with manual functions. Mountain Biking, Ski Touring, World Travelling, you want a camera that is small but won't produce mediocre shots. After using a DSLR, I wanted a camera with similar performance without the bulk. The Canon G15 delivers the goods. Although a little bulkier then the average point n shoot, the G15 still can be stuffed into a bike jersey or ski jacket pocket. The sensor is smaller then a DSLR, but much larger then the average point n shoot. For its size, low light performance is decent. Once you learn to balance ISO, aperture, and shutter speed, you can get some great shots. While indoor shooting with the small flash, I got some outstanding shots. The TV or time value function, set the shutter speed and everything else is done automatically, is the most valuable asset that this camera has for a user with my interests. Set the shutter speed to 1/1000th, and you can get great action shots without having to adjust the settings every shot. Video is decent, good enough for a digital camera. This camera isn't cheap, but you get what you pay for. I highly recommend it for action sport participants. Recently went on a trip with a friend who brought a Sony NEX mirrorless camera, and the G15 blew it away.

Reviews.Title: WOW WOW WOW
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I own three other Canon point and shoots and 2 DSLRs and if I took every positive aspect of each individual camera, stirred them in a big mixing bowl then baked it, the end result would be this delicious concoction. I've had it out of the box for about 4 hours now and I made myself put it down to write this review. It has nearly every bit of functionality as a DSLR packed into what I would describe as a medium large point and shoot. It's an old-school boxy-style camera bursting with advanced features. I will mention that the boxy style is where my one con comes into play- the camera is at least double the weight of my largest point and shoot and because it's boxier and less ergonomic it was beginning to fatigue my hand a bit after a couple hours (however, my eventual hand deformity is a small price pay for the joy of using it). Now, I'll just mention a few highlights of my short time playing with it. First, I was not aware but know now that it takes HDR photos and processes the image in camera or you can use the bracketed images to create the image in 3rd party software. It dials in a sky-high ISO of 12000 which of course didn't produce the best images when I tested it but I say ya never know when you just might need it and it doesn't hurt to have the option. I'm accustomed to shooting in RAW and Aperture Priority mode on my DSLRs and this of course, allows me the same freedoms. The aperture range spans a wonderfully fast f1.8 with great bokeh to an all-encompassing f8.0. An initial selling point for me was the hot shoe providing the ability to attach an external flash but the small convenient on-camera flash with it's plethora of controls allows nearly the same results as my speedlite (nearly, not all). I'm also excited to use the easily accessible dedicated exposure compensation dial right on the top which I'm sure will be a game changer for me. I really could go on and on but suffice it to say that if you're a serious shooter- this is the true definition of bang for your buck! It's not an inexpensive point and shoot but there's a very solid reason for that- lots and lots of bang!In a nutshell-  If you use and enjoy the freedom of a DSLR, you'll get 85% of that same freedom and creative manipulation without the bulk of all the gear.

Reviews.Title: The perfect photographer's companion!
Reviews.Author: Dennis Vogelsang
Reviews.Content: I'll keep this review short and to the point:After trying to find the right 'compact' camera to take with me when not lugging around my DSLR and trying several different ones, including the Fuji X100 and Canon's G1X, I finally found what I was looking for: The Canon G15.Sure, the X100 has a better APC-S sized sensor and a brilliant viewfinder but that's where it ends for me. The X100 lacks fun and having no zoom gets old very quickly. The G15's sensor is surprisingly good and combined with the new Digic 5 processor and f/1.8 lens, it matches the X100's low light performance.I'm not even going into talking about Canon's G1X. All I can say is how disappointed I was with that camera. The G15 outperformance the G1X convincingly and I have friends that own the Canon G1X (and the Fuji X100) and are now wanting to swap over to the G15.The Canon G15 is a high performing compact and at around $400, fantastic value for money!If there was one criticism that I would give the G15, is that the viewfinder is useless and it would loose half a star for that, but since that's not possible, I'm happy to give this little gem the full 5 stars rating. Two thumbs up!D.Vogelsang Photography

Reviews.Title: street photographys best friend (chicago,ill)
Reviews.Author: photopoet55
Reviews.Content: I bought the canon G15 for low light and street photos and its proven to be an all around stealth camera.The video that it produces is great,I am very pleased with the results.It compliments my 5dmk2 very well.

Reviews.Title: so far, so good
Reviews.Author: intotheblues
Reviews.Content: I am definitely a Canon girl. Everytime I try a different brand, I always make the switch back to Canon.I was wanting a high quality camera that wasn't just a point and shoot, and wasn't a full DSLR. I've got both, and was looking for middle of the road, best of both world type of thing. Something that wasn't super heavy but still gave me high quality photos. My hope was to be able to take this on vacation and not have to lug around a DSLR all of the time. Once the price on this dropped to something I was comfortable paying, I snached it up.So far, it's been great. The photos come out clean and crisp, and its really simple to use. I was nervous about how the photos would turn out, becuse the screen makes the photos look *terrible*... But once you open them on a computer and get a better look, they're much cleaner. But seriously, the screen image is horrible. Blurry, and really low quality. I'm still not sure if that the camera's fault or mine.Used the camera at Christmas, and got some really fun shots. Also took this to the Georgia museum, and the photos came out pretty well. For just the few times I've used it around the house taking stupid photos of the dog and cats, I've got pretty good results. I'm still playing with all of the settings, but I think it'll be a good camera to have as an aside to a DSLR. Will it be the only camera I take on vacations? Probably not (don't want to chance it!) but for fun outtings and adventures, this will definitely b the camera I take.

Reviews.Title: Portable Guy wont exchange this camera or take return
Reviews.Author: scott rennard
Reviews.Content: We finally opened our Brand new Canon Powershot G15, powered up battery, turned it on...and get message on the screen, LENS ERROR, SHUTTING DOWN...  this continued multiple times, no idea why, its been sitting in the box, its supposed to be a brand new camera, probably not or damaged in shipping, we contacted PORTABLE GUY, who does business on Amazon, they refused to take return and/or exchange, so Im planning to just ship at my Own cost back to Amazon and either get credit to credit card or a NEW camera in place, will see what happens.  In the meantime, I would not suggest Portable Guy as they have not helped in any way.

Reviews.Title: High-calibre Canon - marred only by lack of extras...
Reviews.Author: Autolycus "Autolycus"
Reviews.Content: After looking at many, buying some and using a few compact cameras recently, the Canon Powershot G15 ticks (almost), all of my boxes. The plus features include the solid build quality, fast f1.8 lens, optical viewfinder and slimmer design - though a folding LCD would have been nice. Sigh... So far, images have been sharp & it has functioned as faultlessly as we expect all Canons to these days - so why only a Four-star rating? The answer is in what's not in the box... When are Canon going to realize that customers don't like being short-changed with the little things...? These include (or don't, in this case), an absence of the USB download cable - even though we probably all have several spares in various drawers - and the worst of all, No Instruction Book... We all know that putting a camera user guide on CD doesn't save any paper at all - but it does shave a few cents off the manufacturing cost, so makes the bean-counters look good. This is a mistake. Even if we print our own manual on double-sided A4, then trim and bind all 316 pages of this particular guide, that's still wasting a lot more paper than would be the case if Canon simply printed all their user guides - in proper paper book form - in multiple languages and all in one central printing works somewhere. So, come on Canon. Kick out the accountants, give us back our books and we'll all be voting 5 stars next time - like when the G2-x comes out next year with the same large sensor but an even faster lens...

Reviews.Title: If you do adventure travel this is not the camera for you
Reviews.Author: Booklover
Reviews.Content: I bought the G15 and the quality of the photos was impressive. It is easy to handle although if you are going on a long trip I highly recommend taking the manual with you (you will have to download it onto your computer or print a hard copy). The settings are complicated for a high end point and shoot. It is also a relatively delicate camera. I had used the camera for less than a week on a trip when the lens stuck in the open position. The camera had been handled carefully--there was no neglect. The manual warns the user that wind or rain can cause the lens to stick. This is not a waterproof camera, but the idea that you must avoid using it on a windy or rainy day (obviously the camera should be protected from rain), suggests that this is a camera best suited for use indoors or on a sunny day. The repair was over $220. Canon said the warranty did not apply as they found water inside the camera. There was no proof that this was the case. If you decide to buy the G15 and take it on a trip, take a backup.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera!!
Reviews.Author: Prakash CJ
Reviews.Content: I bought this for my daughter. The lens is f1.8 at wide and is powerful enough to capture decent pics without needing a flash. There is a manual setting that will help her learn some of the more complex techniques. A great camera from Canon, the battery seems to go on forever on a full charge. Very happy with the purchase!

Reviews.Title: Excellent Deisgn
Reviews.Author: Patrick
Reviews.Content: This is my first Canon Point and Shoot camera.  The picture quality and the functions are excellent for a point and shoot camera.  Even though I am a Nikon fan for last 35 years, this camera that Canon built does change my mind.  I just love it.  Great product from Canon.  The only thing that I don't know is whether the flash mechanism is reliable or not.  If the flash is fixed, it would be a perfect point and shoot camera.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: TuckerMom
Reviews.Content: I am a novice, so I am sure I am not getting the full potential out of this little beauty!  Even though I just use "auto" most of the time, my pictures are amazing!  Very fast shutter focus (not missing all the shots I was before with my previous camera), great in low light conditions, fantastic zoom.  At first, I was concerned because my zoom pictures seemed a little blurry after the shot when I looked on the display screen, but when you review pictures, they are crystal clear!  Amazing!  I got some really amazing zoom shots without a tripod!  Love this camera!  Compact and great pictures.  I should take the time to REALLY learn how to use all the features!

Reviews.Title: Great camera for near and far photos, short videos
Reviews.Author: Sharon H
Reviews.Content: One of our sons, who is an amateur photographer, recommended this camera for our level of expertise. He was right on. It is easy to use, takes terrific photos, and has been all we were looking for. Light enough to carry all over, good in high levels and low levels of light, focuses well in automatic but not too complicated to use with personal settings.

Reviews.Title: Wonderful quality, you'll think you have an SLR.
Reviews.Author: dog lover
Reviews.Content: I used a regular point and shoot in the past only because they were petite and I needed to be able to hold a camera in one hand while doing dog photography for petfinder. The other hand needed to be free to hold treats, toys, etc. I was never satisfied with the point and shoot quality.This camera, with such a fabulous lens and so much lighter in 2013 with the G15 model, gives me crisp pictures and I love being able to change the settings/speed to capture lovely images of wiggly dogs. In bright sunlight, I have been able to take amazing action pictures.This camera is an absolute must if you are looking for very satisfying pro quality pictures, very close or equal to SLR quality, in a camera that is very easy to carry, hold, and adjust. No, it won't fit in a pocket but the photography results are so much better, it's worth hanging it around your neck.

Reviews.Author: james
Reviews.Content: I wanted a compact camera with the ability to take great pictures. This camera is absolutely that. The features, ease of use and picture quality are fantastic. I understand why the Canon G series have such a good reputation.

Reviews.Title: Nice camera
Reviews.Author: Number One
Reviews.Content: When I was getting this camera, I was debating between 1) Canon G15, 2) Sony RX100, 3) Panasonic Lumix LX7 and 4) Canon S110 and in the end I settled on the G15. I want a solid P&S; camera that is very easy to use (I plan to use in auto mode like 95% of the time). As a prudent buyer, I dutifully did some online research and arrived at this conclusion: if budget is not a consideration, the best camera is Sony RX100; for budget conscious, Lumix LX7 seems the best choice. I honestly think all of these cameras are good and since I have a bias towards Canon and I have some hands on experience with the G11 which is amazing, I decided on the G15. That said, I think if I were to pick again, I may choose the Sony RX100 for the smaller form factor. G15 is not really pocket size. So far, based on the 600+ pictures I took on my recent trip, I am satisfied with the performance (shooting speed, image quality) of this camera.

Maybe next time I'll choose a digital SLR.My new pics indoor are great, clear and nitid! But the pics outdoor, not so good, but this is a problem with this photographer here!:-)

Reviews.Title: Best Canon G series so far
Reviews.Author: The Modulator
Reviews.Content: I have owned both the G10 and G11, both of which were stolen.  I liked both of them but Canon has made many improvements with the G15, the biggest improvement being its reduced size.  I also have owned Canon DSLRs but found that because of their size and bulk I rarely used them.  Since my DSLRs were stolen too I have decided to replace them with just one camera...the G15.  The lens is faster than the kit lens found on consumer DSLR zooms and the photos and video are fantastic.  I know the advantages of the larger sensors of DSLRs but I have always adopted the philosophy that the "best" is not always necessary and that "good enough" is most times more than adequate (especially if one views and shows most of their photos via electronic media).  This is especially true if one is not printing huge prints, shooting sports or wildlife, or shooting in very low light.  But small sensor cameras have gotten so good that they are more than "good enough" for 95% of my shooting needs.  Everyone knows the saying that the best camera is the one you have with you and, excluding cell phone cameras, cameras like the Canon G15 are very easily carried and fun to use.  When they make a smart phone that can do everything the G15 can do (and is as fun to use) I'll get one!

Reviews.Title: Love/Hate relationship.
Reviews.Author: S. Adams "S. Adams"
Reviews.Content: I have had this camera about a week and absolutely love most things about it. Super fast focusing, great low light performance, awesome pictures, superb macros, stunning lcd display, great body, and the list goes on. You've seen it all in the other reviews. It's a wonderful camera that I can carry with me for strolls and spur-of-the-moment shots. I would love to have been able to use this for street photography, but because Canon saw fit to do away with the articulated tilt screen, this is not so very practicable now. It's so much easier to get great candid shots of people when you're not so obviously balancing a camera out in front of you at chin level or higher, trying to compose your shot. With a tilt screen or articulated screen you just casually hang your head to look down at the screen, and a quiet, incognito, stealth shot, with the camera hanging low in front at chest level, is so much easier to carry off discreetly and without bringing attention to yourself. With a fixed screen - not. Huge disappointment in that department. What was Canon thinking? Did someone at the design meeting say: "Gentlemen, perhaps we should step back a pace. This camera is so awesome that if we included the tilt screen, like we did for its last 3 predecessors, we'd leave the competition choking in our wake. That would not be fair. Gotta keep the competitors healthy and happy. Let's ditch the tilt screen." How logical was that???So, now I'm faced with trying to decide between this camera and its close competitor the very cool, but somewhat slower-to-focus Nikon P7700. Also, the Nikon's flash is virtually unusable on macro photos because it casts the lens' shadow over your subject. Even though the Nikon also has a 20x zoom lens in its favor and many other awesome features, that slower focus is kind of off-putting... After all, usually you want to actually capture "that" moment, not the one that comes 2.5 seconds later. Also, I love macro photography and really resent that shadow. Who designed that flash anyway???Hence, my dilemma. What to do...?  What to do...?

Reviews.Title: Almost Perfect for a Larger Point-and-Shoot
Reviews.Author: Baycruisers "Baycruisers"
Reviews.Content: There are times that I really don't want to haul around my DSLR and multiple lenses, so I bought a Canon G15 for casual use. There are two features that are especially important to me: an optical viewfinder and RAW file capability. The G15 is one of the few cameras that offers both. I don't always use the optical viewfinder, but I like having it because it's intuitive for someone who typically shoots with a DSLR. I use Lightroom to process image files, which give me more exposure flexibility than regular JPG files.The camera itself is solidly built and even seems a bit heavy. I actually like that. It fits comfortably in my hands and it's easy to hold steady because of the weight. The surface is textured, which gives a feeling of confidence that it's not going to slip out of my hands. (I use an Op/tech hand strap). It's too big and heavy to slip into a shirt pocket,  carry it in my pants or jacket pocket. The controls are easy to manipulate. One feature missing is an articulated viewscreen. Never having had a camera with one, I probably don't know what I'm missing, but it hasn't been something that I've felt I had to have.The camera's features, beyond the usual settings, are too extensive to review here. In my experience, the average shooter uses 25% of a given camera's features 75% of the time because they/we tend to shoot the same subjects under similar conditions. I recommend that you download the manual from Canon to get an idea of the breadth (impressive) of its features and the potential for complexity. If you just want to shoot JPGs in auto or in a scene mode, you may be spending more money than necessary. I shoot primarily aperture priority with RAW files and like the flexibility the camera offers if I wanted to shoot in different settings. Otherwise, the G15 provides the same features most consumer digital cameras offer. To those who are interested the fixed lens provides a 28-140mm equivalent focal length range, but is a stop and a third faster, at F1.8-2.8 then its well-respected predecessor, the G12. That makes it good for indoor use, and you may be able to get away without using a flash in low light conditions with a high ISO. (I hate on-camera flash because it makes everyone look over-exposed and covers too little area, unless you spring for an add-on flash unit, which starts to defeat the purpose of having a small camera.) Focusing is wicked-fast, faster than the G12 according to the specs.The G15 also shoots impressive video, another feature I like, although I can't say I've used it all that much. While most digital cameras shoot video, this is an expected feature, but coupled with a fast lens and solid camera, it beats the heck out of anything your phone can produce.Bottom line: this is the camera I wanted. I wouldn't mind a longer telephoto, but I didn't buy it for nature work. Between the fast lens, RAW capacity, and exposure options, it's what I wanted to carry around when a DSLR is just overkill. And, if my DSLR should fail on a photo shoot, the G15 could step in and take over in many situations. I like having it for a backup.

Reviews.Title: from DSLR to this camera and very happy
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I love the quality and speed of DSLR cameras, but grew weary of lugging around all the equipment and wanting to buy new lenses and accessories all the time. So I decided to try this camera and see how things went. Well, I've very happy. No it's not the same exact quality but still very good! And if you know what you are doing and can set aperture you can still get pretty great portrait shots with the blurred background. Also I can shoot in RAW with this camera and squeak out all the details necessary for great landscapes. One thing I'm particularly impressed with is the auto settings. The camera can analyze a scene and decide the best settings pretty quickly. Even when I took a picture of my toddler, the camera recognized the young child and did a burst of 3 images without me telling it to. I wish I set it to RAW in auto mode. Another minor thing that I love about it is the control dial on the back. Most cameras (even DSLR) have buttons and you have to press several times for control, but this dial is wonderful and makes getting around in the menu and settings and focal points a dream. To summarize, I am once again inspired to do photography! Thanks to this camera.

Reviews.Title: Great at high ISO, but limited to 1 second!
Reviews.Author: Lance Keimig "thenightskye.com"
Reviews.Content: I was tempted to rate this camera two stars because I felt duped when I discovered that I could not use the camera the way I had intended to, but it's such a good camera otherwise that it gets 4 stars.There are many good reviews of this camera, so I will keep this short and to the point. I photograph mainly in low light conditions and at night. I purchased this camera to have a better quality "always with me" camera than my phone for when I didn't want to drag around a DSLR. For this purpose, and for macro shots, this camera excels. It makes a great, unobtrusive travel camera.High ISO performance is excellent, and images are printable to 1600, which is a big improvement over older G series models. This high ISO performance was the reason I purchased the camera. While it has no bulb setting, I figured that the combination of ISO 800-1600 plus the 15 second maximum exposure would allow me to photograph in most conditions excepting moonlit landscapes. What neither Canon's description nor any of the reviews mention is that once you increase the shutter speed past 1 second, you are locked into 80 ISO! In other words, your exposure should be 2 seconds or longer at 200, 400, 800, 1600? Nope, not going to happen. You are stuck at ISO 80. I understand the image quality degrades with the combination of high ISO and long exposure, but geez Canon, if that's what I want to shoot, let me do it! If you are going to advertise high ISO shooting and 15 second shutter speeds, it would really be nice to know that it's one or the other!I almost returned the camera based on this failing, (which I admit is very specific to my needs) but it performs so well in all other aspects that I decided to keep it. I'm still looking for a compact camera that excels at Night Photography.

Reviews.Title: great camera

Reviews.Content: I got this right before a vacation.  It takes great pictures and is really easy to use, I didn't need to spend much time reading the manual or practicing which was great because I didn't have time to do so.  Four stars because it doesn't come with the cable necessary to transfer pictures to my computer, and for a small camera, the strap is ridiculously large.  Also, the battery meter drops from almost full to empty very quickly.  It read as full for a few days and then suddenly went from full to empty in a few hours (an no, I did not accidently just leave it on when this happened).  So charge regularly or risk getting caught with a dead battery.

Reviews.Title: Surprisingly awesome pro-sumer compromise
Reviews.Author: J. Nichols "nicho114"
Reviews.Content: After several years with a low-quality, consumer-grade pinprick sized CCD point-and-shoot, I purchased the Canon G15 for use during a vacation to San Francisco in February.  Though I may not be a professional photographer, I know the basic rules of the game, and can generally do a better job composing a picture using manual settings than any digital camera that I've previously encountered can by itself.  Let me say that, against all expectations, I now shoot pictures mostly in Priority mode, as even full auto on this baby impresses.  I'm not saying that the camera is perfect, but it's a sure sight closer than any other compact camera I've ever handled.First, the good.  Actually, most of this is great.  The G15 has a very "bright" lens (f 1.8 at widest angle), making it excellent for low-light photography despite its' relatively small 1-1.7" sensor.  Further, the camera's anti-shake compensation is excellent, making a low-light superstar acutally usable in-hand, even in darkened museum galleries.  Last on this point, the macro is awesome, due to the physics of the small sensor/short barrel length relationship.  Clear pictures can be had all-around, especially if braced against the ground or some sort of support while shooting, even without flash or AF assist beam.  Colors are bright and punchy, and image noise in .jpg format at low ISO is extremely low.  Format-wise, even though it's something I'm not really advanced enough to tackle on my own, one can obtain Canon RAW format images from this camera, even when shooting to produce .jpg's.  This, actually, is one of the reasons I shoot in priority mode, as one has the option to select an especially high-quality .jpg compression not available in auto, while keeping copies of the RAW images saved to the memory card all at once.Next, the not-so-good.  And, really, at the price-point, there isn't much to go over.  This camera, as many other reviewers have related, blows out exposure pretty easily.  It's best to use the manual exposure compensation control to step back at least 1/3 stop at ALL times, even shooting flashless in low light when your subject has 'high albedo.'  When outdoors in full sunlight?  Shoot at ISO 80, back off exposure at least a full stop, and think about engaging the built-in neutral density filter if you're anywhere near water and/or open sky.  And with flash, turn down intensity and step back from your subject more than you think is wise.  Second, though performance is good at ISO 400, I wouldn't ever use pics shot at over ISO 800 if I were being paid to, unless it's fireworks on the 4th of July.  The image noise is inexcusable.  Maybe if I had a tripod, it would be different, but most images I've shot like this look terrible.  And, performance is heads and tails BETTER than competition in this category of camera, generally speaking.Last, let's go for the neutral.  I am not the world's best photographer...  I don't need a fiddly, fancy DSLR like Japanese tourists or San Francisco's average hipster.  What I wanted, and what I got with this camera, was a reasonably sized tool with modest manual configuration options that is good at shooting sans-flash.  Along with that filthy word 'manual', however, goes a lot of baggage for people who like bells and whistles.  If you want GPS, automatic panorama stitch on-camera rather than just a composition assist, compact ultra-zoom, ultra-wide-angle shooting, etc., look elsewhere.  Fortunately for me, I just wanted a camera that would do what I told it once in awhile, rather than making every picture look like a staticky tinker-toy image.  And, really, this thing still does more than I need it to.  It shoots RAW, which I am not yet educated enough to edit.  It has a hot-shoe flash, which will likely take me a while to learn to use properly so as not to blow out images in an even more spectacular fashion than with just the built-in, pop-up flash.  The menus, while well-laid-out, are deep, and take a little time to fully understand...  But this is still the nicest piece of magnesium alloy casing full of electronics and lenses I've ever had the privelege of owning.

Reviews.Title: Carries on the G tradition...
Reviews.Author: M. E. Balzer "What is Reality?"
Reviews.Content: After owning the original G1, G2, and G7, this continues to carry on the tradition.  Maybe I have smaller hands, but I really like the way this fits in mine and for the most part, the controls are laid out in manner that allows me to make changes quickly (in many cases, with one hand).  I also like the texture of the case. It is not rubbery, but it still seems to be an excellent non-slip surface. I also do not miss the articulating screen since the G7 did not have one, and I find the size, quality and the wide view-angle makes it usable above and below your eye-line.The lens is fast & sharp, and I have noticed that depth-of-field seems better as well. I believe this is a result of using this lens and a larger CMOS sensor. Owning a couple of DSLRs, I am happy to report that the shutter action seems much better as well, probably due to the DIGIC 5 processor, which also allows a few more features like HDR, and multi-frame noise reduction. I also like that you can turn the display off and use the viewfinder only.  This helps reduce battery drain and as a side benefit, allowing faster shutter response.One thing that has not been identified in other reviews is the really good video quality with a separate record button that can be used in any mode and zoom control while recording.  I also like the fact that you can use the digital zoom and there does not appear to be any digital artifacts, which makes wonder if they are using the full sensor for this. I also appreciate the ND filter that is built in.  This really helps when shooting video outdoors on a clear day.There have been concerns about not having a printed manual. There is a detailed manual and it is in PDF format on the CD, or on Canon's website.  I personally do not think this is a problem since I have many ways to read PDFs and actually prefer my iPad as a reading device.  Also, if you put the PDF in the cloud, you always have access to it.My only complaints and they are minor, is still not offering an external mic input or WIFI.  WIFI would be nice for instantly pushing an image or video up to the web, but I guess if this is important to you can always use eye-Fi or similar type products.After using my wife's iPhone or my own Galaxy Nexus, I can say that having a cameras like this still provide much more flexibility.  I find this to be perfect portable camera that does fit in your pocket if you wear cargo pants, jacket, or camera vest.  Personally, if know that I will be shooting, this will either be on a lanyard around my neck, or in my hand.

Reviews.Title: Seriously flawed camera
Reviews.Author: Tom XYZ
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera about a month before I went on a vacation. I tried it out on a variety of everyday situations, and it seemed to work reasonably well, although the viewfinder turned out to be even more worthless then mentioned in other reviews. The wide angle was less wide than my previous camera, but I thought it would be OK for most pictures. It wasn't until I started using it on my trip that I discovered that this camera has very serious flaws which are especially evident at long distance shots. When shooting at maximum wide angle, the LCD  shows a wider field of view than the camera can actually photograph. Everything looks good on the LCD up to pressing the shutter button, but when the display comes up afterward, the result is cropped picture about 5-10% smaller on the LCD screen (and on the memory card) than was shown in the preview. If you try to take a near maximum width picture of a wide building, the sides get cut off. If you notice the cropping when the two second display comes up, in theory you can back up and take an overly large picture, but I found in many city situations the combination of the limited wide angle capability and this cropping made taking the picture of a moderately wide building or similar subject impossible. There was an even worse problem, however. Every so often I would take a carefully composed photo, and the the result would the a picture skewed up or down by about 20%, from what was shown in the viewfinder when I clicked the shutter. It turns out that you can carefully click the shutter, wait for the screen to go dark and the shutter sounds to complete, but apparently the camera has still not captured the image. I found I had to wait and hold the camera steady for a couple of seconds or so after the shutter click to make sure the picture registered properly. To be really safe, you need to wait for the preview to come up and look at it carefully. Needless to say these problems are a disaster if you are taking any sort of action scene. I've never had this sort of problem with any other digital camera. Canon PowerShot G15 12MP Digital Camera with 3-Inch LCD (Black)

Reviews.Title: Great little camera
Reviews.Author: Glo E. Wall "Knittingloie"
Reviews.Content: I ordered this camera a week ago and it came today (free shipping).  I wanted it to replace a G10 which was also a good camera, just a little beat up with wear and not working as well as it used to.  Before buy this camera I bought another Canon product, the PowerShot SX500IS which I returned after 2 days (to a store) mostly because I hadn't realized it didn't have a view finder.My first (so far only) annoyance with this camera is it didn't come with a memory card at all.  Perhaps it said that in the ad, I doubt it.  Fortunately, I kept the one from my G10 and that fit fine.  While the battery was charging I started to study the camera and was alarmed that I couldn't find the self-timer button. One of the reasons I've bought several Canons in a row is they tend to have the same location or at least the same symbol for the self-timer.  However, after a short time I stumbled across the "short cut" button and without being extremely technically smart, I was able to figure out how to set my "short cut" to the self timer which is very wonderful.  Sorry I don't remember what other choices there were but it was many.  I'm 64, my learning curve is not as fast as it once was but I can read.  There are certain kinds of things I let others do for me if they are around.  But since my pets don't have  thumbs, I managed to set the date, time, country, attach the camera strap by myself.I'm not sure how long the battery took to charge because I left the house for about 1 1/2 hours and it was done when I got back.I have an iMac and the photos transferred well into iPhoto.  I've taken about 20 photos, some indoor, some out and so far only used the Auto mode.There was one review which said the feel of the camera was like sandpaper.  I guess to some extent that is true but it doesn't seem annoying to me.

Reviews.Title: Best by far
Reviews.Author: BallaghMan
Reviews.Content: Like most reviewers I love this small but highly effective camera.  I'm not a pro but like to take a good, well framed picture with alive colors and some nice B and W portraits, and especially in low light where I don't want a flash to wash things out.  This does the job and more.  The menu and capabilities are likley way beyond most users, but with time, as you dig into the menu, one can become more imaginative - for example, I have one of the two custom buttons set for portrait setting in B and W, the other for outdoor "Program" mode with specific color enhancements - done with some adjustments here and there (saved - and thus a huge time saving when youre shooting).The big plus is the alive vibrant pictures you get from a rel small package, lighter and easier than an SLR for most users.  The issue of whether the screen is hinged or not is not an issue for me or most users I suspect.A small word of caution - the automatic lens cover is delicate - I spilt some syrup on our older G12 lens cover (same design as the G15) and it jammed it badly - the result of leaving the camera face up on the dining table at a family dinner......ugh.

Reviews.Title: Great point and shoot
Reviews.Author: Melanie

The resolution is very high for a point and shoot and the RAW files can handle photoshop manipulation. Reviews.Title: Nice camera
Reviews.Author: Yee
Reviews.Content: The Canon G15 takes great pictures. However, there were a few minor negatives I've discovered. I was disappointed to find out after its purchase that it neither has a "bulb" mode nor does the package come with a USB transfer cable. The USB transfer cable is necessary to upgrade the firmware (no update available at this time), required to install the software via the provided CD's installation application, and eliminates having to remove the SD card from the camera to transfer your photos. Lastly, the initiation of movie recording is different from other manufacturers' actions. The G15 has a "dedicated movie button", which is not unusual; what is strange is that the movie button is the only way you can begin recording your video. The camera has a movie scene mode on the mode dial; however, when the movie scene mode is selected, pressing the shutter button takes a still photo instead of initiating video recording. The manual makes it seem like this is a feature, but this shutter button behavior seems counterintuitive.
