Reviews.Author: A. CALDWELL
Reviews.Content: This is one very versatile camera. For the price you pay, you will find A camera that is the Best I have ever used. I could not find a better camera for the price. This along with a $50 dollar photo and you will be putting out pictures like a pro. Easily the best photo I've own and with 7 grandchildren, I will be quite busy for a while. Thank you Cannon for the G15

Reviews.Title: Why no articulated LCD Screen?
Reviews.Author: Gmen
Reviews.Content: The Reason for a fixed display is to entice people to move up to G1X (with articulated Screen) where as G15 (now only fixed Screen).  But Canon never expects that GIX would be a flop. The selling point of G1X is the overly large Sensor. But to keep the camera size not too much bigger, the Lens have to be slower & no close-up.  Thinking people will buy a large Sensor, by giving up other features, was a mistake. People buy the camera to use, then they show it off. If it is not good to use, they just don't buy it.  Assuming the slower G1X sales would make up by higher sales volume on G15 did not materialize because of the G15 fixed screen. And with all the competitions, it is no longer the only good choice.  So what was started as a good give-and-take of features for the two cameras had turned into a nightmare for both. People don't buy G1X for the slow and non-close-up Lens and don't buy G15 for the non swing Screen.Solution: G1X - Increase the size of the camera for a faster Lens and better Closeup  or reduce Sensor size to approx four-third, also for faster & better close-up Lens.  G15 - swing Screen. If Canon is not reducing G1X Sensor size,  then it should Increase the G15 Sensor size somewhat.  G15 - has the best overall built camera with best software, so don't make dumb (backward) moves anymore. Keep on improving and it will stay on top of the competitors.

Reviews.Title: Slight upgrade from the G12
Reviews.Author: Nathan J. Churchill
Reviews.Content: This camera is smaller and lighter than the G12 and has a better lens.  The controls are similar (maybe slightly better but not necessarily - just different - easy to get used to anyway).  However, the lack of a tilt screen and the matte finish are disadvantages.  The matte finish scratches other items in your bag (if you carry it around like I do with my wallet and sunglasses, etc, in a satchel).  And the lack of a tilt screen cramps my style a lot. If you are upgrading from a G12 I'd wait for the G16.  If you're in the market for a good point-and-shoot camera, complaints aside, the G15 is an excellent camera offering a good mix or portability, features and quality images.  I've had about 8 different Canon G cameras.  I like them.

Reviews.Title: The best camera I've ever used
Reviews.Author: Ghost 007
Reviews.Content: The best camera I've ever used, although the price is little high for me. The video quality is good but the sound seems not in a perfect condition. Anyway, I use it most for taking photos.

Reviews.Title: Not a toy
Reviews.Author: tbnh
Reviews.Content: I have a Canon 5D, which is much bigger and heavier.  This camera operates in a similar way; familiar controls; Canon high quality.  It is small, however, and even in my small hands it feels a bit cramped.  Also, because of it's size I was lulled into thinking I could throw it in my backpack and not worry.  Two weeks after I got it, I dropped my backpack on the sidewalk, and it must have landed with the camera down.  It dented the lens ring and damaged two of the buttons, making them inoperable; Back to Canon for a costly repair.  Now I wouldn't buy this camera without a protective case - which I quickly got.  I would recommend the camera since it does make very good images, but I would advise treating it carefully.  It's not the toy it sometimes feels like.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful camera!
Reviews.Author: Sebastian Rojo
Reviews.Content: Of course I need to use it more to see how really good it seems to be-Really good features for a powershot!Saludos

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Hivoltage
Reviews.Content: Don't have time to go into details but this camera met all my expectations, Great pictures, great manual controls and great menu system I have zero complaints!

Reviews.Title: Great auto-lighting and battery, horrible barrel distortion
Reviews.Author: MHP777
Reviews.Content: I have an earlier-model PowerShot A570. I wanted to upgrade to this G15, thinking it would be an amazing way to upgrade, considering all the good reviews I found for it on the Internet. I got it out of the box and took a few photos in auto mode. From photo 1, everything in the corners of the photo skewed outward. This looked especially annoying with people's faces and with walls and curtains and hanging pictures. Ever see a person's face in a black hole warp? Get a person on the side of a photo taken with this camera.I emailed customer support, sure something was wrong with the camera. They tried to help, but nothing worked. I called technical support. They tried to help, but nothing worked, and they said I should send it in to the Canon service center on the east coast. I ponied up $18 in UPS charges to insure and send the thing--obliterating the savings I had gained by buying it form Amazon instead of an actual store. Canon held onto it so long, without a resolution, that the time passed when I could just return it to Amazon--so I can no longer return it, because of Canon. Finally they contacted me and said it might be barrel distortion, but that this was all within the specs for the camera. They asked me to describe the problem again. I did, and they said they would look at it again and get back to me.In the meantime, I looked up barrel distortion on the Internet (I did not previously know what that was) and found a couple of sites explaining that this thing is inherent to wide-angle zoom lenses, and that the only way to fix it is either to not take photos in wide angle, or to Photoshop it out using a lens filter. Well, you don't actually get a choice of taking a photo in wide angle or not with this camera, unless you zoom every photo, because the un-zoomed setting is always wide-angle. Also, Photoshop does not yet have a lens filter for this particular lens--Photoshop does have a lens filter for the G10 and G12, but the G15 lens is special because of its F1.8-F2.8 range. I tried using Photoshop to clean up some of my photos, but the G10 and G12 lens filters didn't work. And in any case, I shouldn't have to use Photoshop on every picture I take.Finally Canon decided to send me the camera back, about a week ago, well into the start of February, a month after I sent it in for repair. They did nothing to it. It still works the same. And I can't send it back to Amazon to get my money back.The camera does have excellent automatic light adjustment and battery charge life, far better than my A570. But my A570 takes far better pictures, since it does not warp people's heads into black holes.If you looking for a camera to take normal photos, DO NOT BUY THIS CAMERA. Only buy it if you intend to use it for wide-angle shots with the telltale barrel distortion, because that is what you will get.

Reviews.Title: Overwhelming disappointment
Reviews.Author: A disappointed Canon fan
Reviews.Content: I have been using a Canon G7 since 2005.  Loved it, took well over a thousand pictures, good zoom, good resolution,  good color  The camera produced some unbelievably good results.  I was very happy to see the release of the G15 with its specs and features.  The G15 was a complete disappointment.Almost from the first time I turned it on the lens refused to retract and it gave the "lens error" message.  This was the result almost 50% of the times I tried to shut it down.  After much frustration I searched on the net and found that Canon has this problem with other cameras, mainly the S100.  The net was full of horror stories about Canons refusal to fix or recall the camera.  I understand that just recently, after years of net bashing, Canon has agreed to repair all S100s regardless of age.After reading the suggestions on the net I checked my G15 and when the lens is extended the lens barrels are actually loose to the touch.  They can be gently moved up or down a slight amount.  My old G7 is tight with no movement.My opinion is that it is a lack of quality control somewhere in Canon's manufacturing process.  Therefore any replacement could have the same defect or it could develop a year or two later after it is out of warranty.  I returned the G15 and am looking for a substitute brand.I would not buy this camera and I would not recommend it to anyone.

Reviews.Title: Great camera.
Reviews.Author: Jerlyn Pe
Reviews.Content: I was a little disappointed that for the price you pay, no memory card was included, even if it were a small capacity one and how much would it cost to include the cable to transfer pictures to computer. I am sure the manufactures pay pennies for those cables.Using the camera, and enjoying the beautiful pictures and clear videos made those little annoyances of memory card and cable fade away.

Reviews.Title: okay but not in the box user manual
Reviews.Author: HoracioMartinez
Reviews.Content: HDI also brings cable, or a cable to transfer files to the computer, a very poor packaging and if the box falls, breaks the camera

Reviews.Title: Good camera. No cables included.
Reviews.Author: Mirek
Reviews.Content: Good camera. Very good picture quality.I used to have G12 before for a few months. Upgraded to G15 expecting better picture quality and I'm not disappointed.What is missing compared to G12 that is no articulating screen, which is very convenient occasionally . Maybe it should be two models offered, one with and one without it.I didn't know it in time of buying G15 and I'm really disappointed.Also it would be nice to have a touchscreenIf you buying G15 be aware no USB nor TV cables are included. There are included with G12.Cheap side of Canon. Because of it four stars only.

Reviews.Title: Glorified point and shoot...
Reviews.Author: Shinebox
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for the lens and image quality but I have to say after a week of shooting with this camera I just can't seem to get a high end shot. Maybe it is not made for photographing sunsets or other forms of manual mode type of pictures. I just could not get a good shot of a sunset with this camera over the last few days of having great weather around here. My Panasonic Lumix FZ200 does 10x better and it was a few bucks more. I took photos with my other cameras and got better results. I can't justify keeping around a $450 point and shoot.I really wanted to keep this camera, the build quality is amazing, it is like a brick in your hands which is what i like in a camera, kind of like to feel like it's quality and not plastic.The few pics i took around the house with people came out pretty good but I or the camera kept overexposing the photo, the whites were so bright and I didn't mess with the exposure compensation or anything else. I even tried Intelligent Auto mode and same thing. Weird. I mean the pics were nice but overly bright, nothing some post processing couldn't fix but geez you would think you wouldn't have to edit every pic.ANyway maybe I was doing something wrong with this camera and someone can help me here. Right now it's in the box ready to go back.

Reviews.Title: Good camera - with a crippling "feature"
Reviews.Author: J.Wimmer
Reviews.Content: In general, I would agree with the preceding reviews, rating the G15 as an excellent camera, in particular due to the impressive f1.8 aperture which allows for pictures rivaling those of average SLRs.As long as you don't plan to take night shots.If you want to take exposures longer than one second, ISO is suddenly limited to 80. No workaround possible. This makes the camera practically useless for long exposure shots (stars, moonlit/candlelight scene etc.).Even if there are relatively few situations where I would need long exposures, the fact that I cannot do them at all with the camera means that I wouldalways need to take a second camera with me (e.g. on vacation), which of course defies the purpose of buying a compact camera.I don't know what rode Canon to put this "feature", yet again (at least also present in the S100), into the G15. It effectively cripples this otherwise excellent camera to an extent that I have to return it and buy a competitor's model.

Reviews.Title: Good camera:
Reviews.Author: dnelms
Reviews.Content: I've had many of the G series Canon cameras. Some of the automatic features are amazing. If you're interested in macro photography this is not the camera for you.I bought this camera for my wife and it is doing a very good job of serving the purpose.

Reviews.Title: Ok Camera, Expected more
Reviews.Author: Jorge E. Castillo
Reviews.Content: I am not an expert with cameras, however, I would have expected more from a US$450+ camera. Having said that, the camera performs well but it could be improved. My screen was damaged after it barely made contact with another surface. Now I can't see anything through the screen. The view-finder is not accurate and it doesn't function well--this was a complete design fail by Canon. Do not expect to use this as a point-and-shoot product, because it is bulky. Moreover, since the camera screen feels very delicate, the camera needs to be protected with a camera bag. The flash does not pop-up automatically (it has a button to eject), and even when it is up, the camera fails to use the flash in some low-light conditions in Auto mode.I have owned more than 6+ Canon cameras in the past and I wouldn't say I love this product.

Reviews.Title: Maybe just not the camera for me
Reviews.Author: S. Maxham
Reviews.Content: I was in the market for a pocket sized camera for traveling (I own a Canon 60D, but at times it is just too bulky for what I need.) The G15 sounded like just what I needed - viewfinder, RAW, compact, external hot shoe, high ISO, many features similar to my 60D.I've used this camera all of 5 times, and I will be returning it. The battery won't hold a charge for more than 20-ish photos, the camera actually *heats up* under the grip where the battery is housed, the camera will regularly turn itsself off with the lens extended, and yes, the viewfinder is kind of useless (yes, yes, paralax -- I was spoiled with the 60D.) Minor gripe for not including a paper manual (lame.)I am gong to return this - it may be some sort of fluke, crappy battery, etc. I WANT to like this camera a LOT. But right now I can't trust it to last half an hour, much less a trip. :(I will update my review after camera #2. But I will also admit I am buying a different camera on Amazon on the day-after-Christmas sales to hedge my bets, just in case.C'mon, Canon, don't let me down....Update:So, I turned the previous camera back in and got a new one of the same model. So far, zero issues of the first camera, which leads me to believe it was just unlucky chance. Very pleased with new/same camera so far. I haven't played around with all the features as I still have to print out the manual (still lame). I really like the heft of this camera, and it fits nicely into my sweatshirt pocket, so I take photos all the time. I do get a little nervous just throwing the camera into my pocket with the delicate lens cover, but so far so good. The viewfinder is no good unless you have time to set up a shot and correct for the errors not being lined up with the lens. Otherwise its screen all the way.Update 2 (Aug '13):Less impressed with this camera over time. The replacement camera is still operating normally, so its not that. Just got back from vacation and am feeling less than pleased.- I *really* dislike the lag after pressing the shutter button. Just a split second, but enough that I missed shot after shot.- This one is personal opinion: I do not like having to use the screen to compose shots. I much much prefer the viewfinder/eyepiece, but the offset from the lens is so bad its not really an option.- That delicate lens cover? Yeah, my lens got scratched. And yes I do own a case for it. Obviously it happened some other time, something brushed against it enough to move the cover and put a nice mark on my glass.- The auto/P/Tv/Av etc dial on top turns *too* easily. I'd be snapping away happily, walk away looking at my pictures and realize the dial had slipped to SET yet again. Arg!- The auto focus often seemed to have a mind of its own. We regularly disagreed about what it was supposed to be focusing on.- I did enjoy playing with some of the creative effects.I'll look into having the glass fixed, but I'm concerned it'll be too cost prohibitive. I'd love for this to be my grab and go camera, but I really can't recommend it as such. I'm not sure what I would recommend it for, except perhaps its size? Your mileage may vary. (shrug)

Reviews.Title: Canon PowerShot G15
Reviews.Author: Jo Adams
Reviews.Content: Haven't had the time that is required to learn how to use this camera properly, but can tell that it will be the one I have been looking for.The Canon SX260 stutter speed was to slow, causing missed shots.

Reviews.Title: perfect
Reviews.Author: LEAVES
Reviews.Content: this is not a brand new camera, but it looks like a brand new one. it is very valuable. love it.

Reviews.Title: Mine broke...
Reviews.Author: K. Chipman
Reviews.Content: I got this camera for Christmas from my parents. They ordered it from Amazon the first of December. While on a family trip for spring break, it broke. The lens cover is automated. It has several different parts that retract up into the camera when you turn it on. I have no idea how it happened, but one of the parts came dislodged. It was the only camera I had on my trip so I tried to push it up myself. Now it appears as if the lens may be scratched. The company I purchased it from (through Amazon) will not let me return it. My only option is to send it to Cannon for repair. I can only hope that it will be covered under warranty. I'm very sad that such an expensive camera only lasted 2.5 months.

Reviews.Title: Mixed Bag
Reviews.Author: Tokugawa Ieyasu "Careful Buyer"
Reviews.Content: Got the G15 to update from the G12. While the video on the G15 is superior to the G12, the still photos are not consistently sharp. You expect more from a camera with this price tag. If this is your only camera you might be disappointed with the results of shooting some important event. No one wants photos that are not sharp when shooting precious memories. Go with the G12 even though it is an older model. Not sure what's up with Canon these days. The G1X was also a disappointment.

Reviews.Title: I changed my mind
Reviews.Author: Daniel D. Hogan
Reviews.Content: I have been meaning to come back and edit this review for a long time.What I said about the video capabilities of the camera still hold, but as a camera it is a great tool.I started walking early every morning and at first I was taking my 2009 Canon SX1-is, but it was banging around hanging from my neck, so I took out the G-15.  I bought a leather case for the camera and it was awkward to to get it off while out taking pictures, so I took it off and now the G-15 has been through heat and rain and cold and snow and has been dropped and bumped and covered in dust and it just keeps on ticking.  And some beer has splashed on it too when taking pictures of bands.On the coldest days of the recent winter the camera operated flawlessly and took some amazing shots.  It is not great for action shots, but for low light sunrises and my bird watching, it is excellent.  The fisheye lens feature is also great and it has a pretty robust bunch of settings for most imaginable shots.The viewfinder is worthless, but the non-articulating screen is excellent and it has the great dual axis electronic level display.The real star  is the the camera's 28mm Wide-Angle 5x Optical Zoom lens with a focal length of 6.1-30.5mm (35mm film equivalent: 28-140mm) achieves f/1.8-f/2.8, it is amazingly versatile in every situation.All this fits in your pocket, has awesome battery life and is incredibly durable.  I just clean it regularly and think that next time I want a great video camera, I will get a video camera, but when I want a camera that can go anywhere and take great pictures, I grab the G-15.[Wow, third Canon camera and this one is small and has great battery life, but the pictures aren't great and the HD video, which is why I bought this camera, is horrible because the picture is great, but the sound is rice krispies meets milk.  Plus, less than 90 days return cost me -- if I had bought this camera at Best Buy or Wall Mart, they would, at minimun replace the camera to make sure I didn't get an expensive lemon for no extra cost.  Amazon might lose a regular customer over this camera.]

Reviews.Title: Doesn't have a grip
Reviews.Author: BENGAL
Reviews.Content: I've always had a camera with a "grip" and this one didn't.  Just wasn't comfortable and easy to use.  Returned it and bought Panasonic Lumix FZ200

Reviews.Title: Slighly disappointed
Reviews.Author: Thomas E. Gaglione
Reviews.Content: Was looking for a good new point-and-click as my 6 year old $99 trusty Kodak recently died. Went a few extra dollars for this camera based on all the great reviews. Just got it and used it this weekend. I must say I am not that impressed (though only used the 'Auto' mode). With pictures outside in gorgeous daylight the highlights are washed out and darks are very dark. Also, the clarity is not really great. Again, I was really expecting better pics than my 6 year old $99 Kodak, the fact that it's 6 year newer technology, and that it's about $100 over the average top rated point and clicks out there.. I am having buyers remorse at the moment. Maybe I need to get more into the manual settings... ? As far as video, decent, but the wind noise was bad even on a relatively non windy day. Right now I am thinking the extra $ was not worth it here.

Reviews.Title: 3 g10's and a g12
Reviews.Author: Katie Mclane
Reviews.Content: I have worn out three G10's and now have a G12.  This series is great. Good sharpness and color.  The G 10 was used by the National Geographic photographer that shot theBP oil spill. I don't have the G15 but I will soon.  A great all around camera for scenics and candids while I have the long lens on the EOS. The underwater housing is great too. It works great.

Reviews.Title: Blech.  Where's my G9?
Reviews.Author: JV "The V-Man"
Reviews.Content: I had the G9 for years and loved that camera so much.  It was time to upgrade to HD Video, so I did and finally sold my G9 on Amazon, and went after the G15.  I don't like it, I don't use it, I am not sure I ever will.  It's so different from the G9.  I shouldn't have sold that camera.

Reviews.Title: Disappointed with hardcase design and buttons
Reviews.Author: Marilyn Reinarz
Reviews.Content: The hand grip was the most disappointing.  I felt the grip was not big enough to keep the camera from falling out of my hands. I ride on the back of a motorcycle with my husband driving and I'm busy taking pictures.  My older Canon Powershot has a larger grip, so the wind isn't able to whip the camera out of my hand, and I can keep the camera steady despite the airflow frm any direction.  I also take many photos holding the camera under, over and in things that my head won't fit into.  The new buttons on the G15 get in the way, and change the settings.  When reviewing my photos, and try to turn the cam for friends to see, my thumb hits something that takes the photo off the screen.  Its very annoying to go back, find the photo and try to turn the screen to share the photo with friends. Finally, the photos are beautiful as I would expect, but would rather add a Wide Angle lens, than to have every photo taken with Wide Angle. I would rather have the normal lens and switch out when needed.

Reviews.Title: Canon Saves a buck at customer cost!
Reviews.Author: Johnnie P Robnett
Reviews.Content: This review highlights Canon and with but minor comments on the camera. I own and have owned a number of Canon cameras and have been satisfied that these products were worth the their cost. That is until now and the lack is for Canon's performance and not the camera. For example, Canon requires a USB Cable (Camera end Mini-B but does not supply one - however they do offer it as an accessory for sale!) according to the supplied Getting Started booklet to upload their software, which includes the User Guide in PDF format (a printed User's Guide is not provided OR offered). Once the cable is acquired and the upload is begun the computer screen has the option to not connect the camera to the computer to upload the software. Supplying the required cable OR sentence in the Getting Started booklet solves this problem. Also, the User's Guide explains how to implement various functions (e.g., setting "Scene options" or "P Mode" options) but does not include how to cancel these selections - this takes experimentation  on the users part - and time is money. In summary, I anticipate the Canon PowerShot G15 will perform up to my expectations but at a cost that was unanticipated nor necessary. I was always taught; "Make buying and operating EASY for the customer!". Canon has seemed to ignored this truth!

Reviews.Title: PLEASE Canon, listen to your users!
Reviews.Author: rmode
Reviews.Content: Ridiculous that Canon won't allow users any manual control in video mode (iso, shutter speed, aperture). This is one of the most requested features ever. Every time Canon release a new p&s; camera, hundreds of people around the net inquire, and the answer is always "no". Such was the case with the s95/ s100/ s110/ G12/ and G1x. Why won't Canon just grant their users this simple request? I (like many others) are supporting other brands because of this one (repeated) kick to the groin by Canon. PLEASE Canon, just add manual control in video like your competitors are doing for us. Pentax did it with the Q, Nikon w/ the V1 & J1, Panasonic w/ the LX-5 & LX-7, Sony w/ the rx100 & NEX Series, Olympus has full manual with the E-P2/3, etc, etc. A $500 "advanced p&s;" should have it. This doesn't (again). Sadly Canon keeps ignoring their user's requests. This (and the G1x) could be awesome. But instead... must keep buying Panasonic's to get it.

Reviews.Title: Optical viewfinder not centered
Reviews.Author: R. Mercer
Reviews.Content: Generally camera ok for what it is.  However, for close up, macro or telephoto (ie 5x optical) the optical viewfinder is a real problem as it isn't even approximately centered with the view screen / captured image.  If you center the picture with the optical viewfinder at 5x only 1/3 of what you see thru it will be captured!  Poor
